**Method for Ingesting Talismans with Corresponding Directions and Incantations:**
One nine concealed in Kan,
Two nine in Kun’s domain,
Three nine emerges from Xuan Zhen,
Four nine shines in Xun’s flame,
Five nine resides in the central position,
Six nine meets Qian’s realm,
Seven nine stands atop Dui,
Eight nine harms the Ghost Gate,
Nine nine ascends to Li’s radiance—
The spirit’s journey unites with the Jade Emperor.

The above incantations follow the directions; ingest the nine talismans, altering the qi incantations for each direction while visualizing the qi’s color of the respective direction, forming a red-orange mass the size of a tangerine, and drawing it into the cinnabar field.

**Secret Incantation for Entering Stillness:**
Primal Yellow circulates qi, eradicating all evil traces.
By the mighty decree of the Most High, peace is bestowed upon the Peach Lord.
The Seven Numinous Ones govern in stillness, their luminous script resplendent in the Yellow Center.
Wu and Ji form the canopy, the Infant Messenger establishes communication.
All meridians merge, all orifices unite in harmony.
The spirit roams the Great Desert—my life knows no end.
Swiftly, swiftly, in accordance with the Ordinance of the Primordial Beginning.

Whenever refining the spirit, enter stillness, burn incense, and recite the incantation seven times in secret.

**Petition for Descent Incantation:**
*Ling Chou Mo Yin □ Mao Le Chen Ni Si.*
Five Spirits Incantation—blow upon the paper.

**Incantation for Receiving Spirits into the Five Palaces:**
Within the Five Primordial Essence Palaces of the Primordial Emperor, all are as one.
The left eye is the Great Yang.
Seal the tongue to the left.
Visualize the Great Yang, direct the gaze to emit liver qi, merging it into azure mist-qi, and receive it into the liver palace.
The right eye is the Great Yin.
Seal the tongue below.
Visualize the right eye to emit lung qi, merging it into white mist-qi, and receive it into the lung palace.

**Heavenly Canopy Heavenly Fire Urgent Seal**
**Golden Wheel Demon-Subduing Seal Formula**

From *you* to *mao*, seal the fingers firmly. The space between the brows is the Heavenly Manifestation. Seal the tongue to the tip. Visualize the Heavenly Manifestation, directing the mind’s intent from spleen toward kidney. Crimson, yellow, and violet qi emerge from the nose, merging into azure, yellow, and white qi, gathering between the brows to form a single five-colored pearl. From the mud-palace, with spirit, welcome the precious pearl into the abdomen and swallow it. Naturally, the five viscera radiate light, and true fire burns away the foul qi within the body. Then behold the Dharma-body like an infant.

**Incantation:**
*Om Haṃ Da Svāhā.*

Seal at *sì*. The incantation reads:
Azure essence, Yang spirit,
Great White of *geng* and *xin*.
Flaming Crimson Emperor,
Lord of *ren* and *gui*.
Bestow upon my *wu* and *ji*,
Unite with my bodily form.
A thousand harmonies, ten thousand unions,
Qi-body attains numinous communion.
Long life and enduring vision,
May I ascend in flight.

Swiftly as the Primordial Beginning’s decree!

Next, visualize the true qi of the Five Directions merging with the five viscera, entering through the crown of the head, traversing the Five Palaces, transforming into a red tangerine, and receiving it into the cinnabar field—swallow the talisman.

**Universal Summons of the Myriad Spirits Incantation:**
By the Primordial Beginning’s decree, the Dao Lord’s kalpic script,
The Three Luminaries’ mysterious Dipper, the essence of sun and moon,
Sixfold divine radiance, elevenfold directional transformations—
I now summon [Name], hasten to descend and commune with the numinous.
Swiftly arrive before the altar, transmit the divine command.

Seal of Jade Purity. When summoning the Five Peaks, seal the Five Spirits. Visualize freely, and the deities of the ten directions will arrive at once—whether as the sound of pines in the ear or conveyed through a youthful messenger, not one will be absent. Guard this secret.

**The Twenty-Four Jade Contracts of the Numinous Treasure for Opening Heaven**
The Master says: A *contract* is a bond, the celestial covenant. The Heavenly Worthy bestows edicts upon the children destined for immortality, first granting jade contracts to await their ascension, passing through the gates of heaven. These jade contracts are distributed among the heavenly palaces, just as earthly offices govern their jurisdictions—each has its constraints, and none may casually approach. Thus, the heavens establish these jade contracts to bestow upon those who study the Dao. Should one’s allotted years expire and the body return to Great Peace, possessing this jade contract allows direct passage to their destined abode. Upholding the celestial edict, soaring beyond the earthly realm, one relies on this contract to traverse the fierce winds. With the left *she* and right *ji* assisting the adept’s ascent to perfection, all depends on the jade contract. Without having personally attained the Dipper’s rank, none may lightly receive it. Violators face heavenly execution. Be vigilant.

The Nine Heavens Jade Contract, also called the Great One Contract—used for opening the gates of heaven, transcending life and death, guiding souls in ascension, and approaching the Nine Heavens, Ten Heavens, Thirty-Two Heavens, the celestial bureaus, the Heavenly Masters, and the Three Generals of the Heavenly Gates.

*Dǎn Zhēn Dá Yuán Nán Zhān Yún Gōng Dāo Dū Ā Xiān Jué Tiān Shā Rén*

The Nine Immortals Jade Contract, also called the Controller of Destiny Contract—used for opening the earthly gates, liberating divine souls, severing earthly bonds, and addressing matters in the Northern Darkness of Mount Fengdu, the Earthly Courts, and all affairs pertaining to the earthly Dao.

*Tán Zhēn Mén Yuán Qián Zhān Lún Gōng Táng Dǒu Shǒu Xiān Xuán Tiān Zhēn Rén*

The Southern Culmen Jade Contract—used for all affairs in the Southern Heavens, the Southern Direction, the Southern Dipper Bureau, the Southern Prosperity Upper Palace, the Southern Court, the Inner Ministry of the Celestial Pivot, the Celestial Pivot Court, and the Vermilion Numinous Fire Prefecture.

*Yīn Xū Yún Fēi Shēn Fàn Xuān Nà Tōng Wǎn Yóu Jiǔ Qián Kūn Xiān Bì*

The Northern Culmen Jade Contract—used for all affairs in the Northern Heavens, the Northern Direction, the Northern Culmen Bureau, the Northern Court, the Grand Mystery Metropolitan Ministry, the Inner Ministry of the Celestial Pivot, and the Northern Darkness of the Yellow Springs.

*Yín Huá Xuán Hé Shí Miǎo Róng Fù Yú Yì Shén Yù Yún Fēi Zhēn Yuán*

The Jade Contract of the Eastern Flower High Minister and Azure Youth Dao Lord—used for all affairs in the Eastern Direction, the Nine Qi of Wooden Virtue, the Fusang Palace, the Great One’s Azure Palace, and the Azure Numinous Primordial Elder Palace.

*Yuán Shǒu Hū Lì Dá Dū Huí Yào Nán Dān Yù Míng*

The Vermilion Brilliance Jade Contract—used by the Southern Marchmount’s Lady Wei and all affairs in the Southern Direction, the Three Qi of the Vermilion Terrace, the Southern Upper Southern Numinous, and the Vermilion Numinous True Elder Palace.

*Yù Kōng Lǜ Chǒu Yún Fù Lǎn Biàn*

The Western Tortoise Luminous Jade Contract—used for all affairs in the White Jade Tortoise Terrace, the Grand Primordial Perfected, the Radiant Numinous Yellow Elder, and the Seven Qi Palace of the Western Direction.

*Pó Sè Jǐng Jì Ā Biàn Fú Sāng*

The Northern Dark Mysterious Brilliance Jade Contract—used for all affairs in the Five Qi Palaces of the Northern Direction, the Five Numinous Mysterious Elder Palace divisions, and the various bureaus of the Northern Dark Northern Sea Water Prefecture.

*Jiǔ Fù Miǎo Chǒu Shā Lí Dòng Mò*

The Central Heaven Supreme Perfected Jade Contract—used for all affairs in the administrations of Penglai and Yingzhou.

*Huì Wú Fú Yù Yóu Pó Yù Jiǔ*

The Solar Lords Jade Contract.

The Lunar Lords Jade Contract

The Dipper Jade Contract

The Upper Primordial Heavenly Palace Jade Contract

The Middle Primordial Earthly Palace Jade Contract

The Lower Primordial Water Palace Jade Contract

The Celestial Vanguard Jade Contract—used for all affairs in the Seven Mansions of the Eastern Direction.

The Celestial Strategist Jade Contract—used for all affairs in the Seven Mansions Palaces of the Southern Direction.

The Divine Guardian Jade Contract—used for all affairs in the Seven Mansions Palaces of the Western Direction.

The Dark Warrior Jade Contract—used for all affairs in the Seven Mansions Palaces of the Northern Direction.

The Azure Thearch Jade Contract—used for all affairs of the Eastern Marchmount Perfected Lord and the Eastern Marchmount Tai Mountain Palace.

The Vermilion Thearch Jade Contract—used for all affairs of the Southern Marchmount Perfected Lord and the Southern Marchmount Heng Mountain Palace.

The White Thearch Jade Contract—used for all affairs of the Western Marchmount Perfected Lord and the Western Marchmount Hua Mountain Palace.

The Dark Thearch Jade Contract—used for all affairs of the Northern Marchmount Perfected Lord and the Northern Marchmount Dai Mountain Palace.

The Yellow Thearch Jade Contract—used for all affairs of the Central Marchmount Perfected Lord and the Central Marchmount Song Mountain Palace.

The aforementioned twenty-four Jade Contracts shall each employ only celestial seal-script. They are to be inscribed upon boards five *cun* in length and two *cun* and four *fen* in width, written in vermilion and presented as decrees to the Jade Thearch. On the day of returning to the True, they may be worn for use, thereby ensuring swift return to one’s original abode without hindrance or obstruction. Should one encounter the issuance of official documents or dispatches from the aforementioned palaces, they may also be employed. For such purposes, use lightweight paper, ground mica as powder, and cinnabar of the eight celestial stems. Invoke the hand-seals of the Supreme Thearch and inscribe the text. Draw *qi* from the southeast and blow upon it, then cut the paper down the middle into two pieces. Affix the left piece to the head of the official document, rendering seals unnecessary. Burn the right piece to ash and mix it with fragrant water from the southeast, then consume it—none shall fail to reach its destination.

**The Gate of Purificatory Prohibitions**
The Master said: In the practice of the Great Daoist Rites, observe the auspicious days of the heavens and maintain a pure fast. Thus shall the Celestial Emperor inscribe your name, and the Nine Mysteries and Seven Ancestors ascend together to the Southern Palace. Your person shall remain pure and fortunate, attaining longevity and immortality. When merit is fulfilled and perfection achieved, blessings shall extend to your lineage. All wishes shall be granted, spirits and ghosts bow in reverence, and the myriad perfected beings shall gather before you.

**The Three Primes**
The fifteenth day of the first month, the fifteenth day of the seventh month, and the fifteenth day of the tenth month.

**Assemblies of the Three**
The seventh day of the first month: the Heavenly Bureau convenes its Promotion and Reward Assembly.
The seventh day of the seventh month: the Earthly Prison holds its Grand Celebration of Life.
The fifth day of the tenth month: the Watery Bureau establishes its Grand Assembly of Life.
The aforementioned Three Primes and Three Assemblies are all days of universal deliverance and karmic assessment.

**The Five Laba Festivals**
The first day of the first month: Heavenly Laba.
The fifth day of the fifth month: Earthly Laba.
The seventh day of the seventh month: Moral Laba.
The first day of the tenth month: Popular Yearly Laba.
Within the twelfth month: the Obstructing Laba day is designated as the Laba for kings and lords, corresponding to the Five Tombs of the *Nayin* system.
On all Laba days, in accordance with the *Sutra on the Profound Kindness of Parents* as expounded by the Heavenly Worthy, one should observe a pure fast, make offerings to departed ancestors, recite scriptures, perform the Dao, and deliver the deceased—thus earning the name of a filial child. To make offerings on other days is to engage in wanton sacrifice; if the deceased are not venerated, the blessings sought will not be attained.

**Days of the Lesser Three Assemblies**
*Gengshen* day: the Corpse Spirit reports one’s transgressions.
*Jiazi* day: the Great Unity reviews the registers of gods and spirits.
One’s *benming* day: the hundred spirits gather before one’s person to tally merits and deeds.

**The Eight Seasonal Nodes**
*Lichun*, *Chunfen*, *Lixia*, *Xiazhi*, *Liqiu*, *Qiufen*, *Lidong*, *Dongzhi*.
On these days, the perfected beings of the eight directions assemble to assess sins, blessings, merits, and transgressions in the Eight Radiant Palace of the Upper Prime. As stated in the *Declarations of the Perfected*: on these days, one should maintain a pure fast and cultivate goodness within the bounds of the Dao. On the day of *Qiufen*, one need not offer apologies. One must not indulge in anger, strife, or the exercise of punitive authority, for these are the greatest taboos of heaven and humanity.

**Days of Seasonal Assemblies**
*Jiawu*: Heavenly Seasonal Assembly.
*Jiashen*: Earthly Seasonal Assembly.
*Jiachen*: Four Seasons’ Assembly.
*Jiazi*: Human Seasonal Assembly.
*Jiaxu*: Five Agents’ Assembly.
*Bingwu*: Heavenly Assembly.
*Renwu*: Earthly Assembly.
*Gengwu*: Solar Assembly.
*Gengshen*: Lunar Assembly.
*Xinyou*: Stellar Assembly.
*Dingmao*: Assembly of Immortals and Perfected Beings.
The third day: Dipper’s Assembly.
One’s birthday: Assembly of One’s Life-Spirit.
On the aforementioned assembly days, it is fitting to perform offerings, invoke blessings, and recite scriptures, for the perfected will descend and respond with favor.

**The Five Mao Days**
*Yimao*, *Dingmao*, *Jimao*, *Xinmao*, *Guimao*.
On all *mao* days, one should receive the fast, enter the chamber facing east, bow in reverence, and cultivate the spirit while nurturing *qi*, awaiting the response of the divine. One may also express one’s intentions, and through consistent practice, the Jade Maidens will descend with talismans.

**Days of the Descent of the Heavenly Worthies and Lords of Qi**
The first day: the Heavenly Worthy of the East descends with the Nine Lords of *Qi*.
The eighth day: the Heavenly Worthy of the South descends with the Three Lords of *Qi*.
The fourteenth day: the Heavenly Worthy of the West descends with the Seven Lords of *Qi*.
The fifteenth day: the Heavenly Worthy of the North descends with the Five Lords of *Qi*.
The eighteenth day: the Heavenly Worthy of the Northeast descends with the Lord of Brahmanic *Qi*.
The twenty-third day: the Heavenly Worthy of the Southeast descends with the Lord of Brahmanic *Qi*.
The twenty-fourth day: the Heavenly Worthy of the Southwest descends with the Lord of Brahmanic *Qi*.
The twenty-eighth day: the Heavenly Worthy of the Northwest descends with the Lord of Brahmanic *Qi*.
The twenty-ninth day: the Heavenly Worthy of the Upper Realm descends with the Lord of Primordial *Qi*.
The thirtieth day: the Heavenly Worthy of the Lower Realm descends with the Ninefold Sovereign Lords.
In shorter months, subtract three days.

**Days of the Descent of the Various Perfected Beings**
The first day: the Northern Dipper descends from the Northwest.
The eighth day: the Lunar Slayer Lord of the Northern Dipper descends.
The fourteenth day: the Envoy of the Great Unity descends from the Northeast.
The fifteenth day: the Three Officials descend.
The eighteenth day: the Great Unity descends from the Southeast.
The twenty-third day: the Eight Divine Envoys of the Great Unity descend from the South.
The twenty-fourth day: the Northern Culmen descends from the Southwest.
The twenty-eighth day: the Great Unity descends from the West.
The twenty-ninth day: the Central Great Unity descends from the Lower Realm.
The thirtieth day: the Great Unity descends from the Upper Realm.
The above is drawn from the *Sutra on Karmic Retribution and Causation*; on these days, it is fitting to make offerings to the perfected spirits.

**The Four Commencement Days**
The first day of the first month, the first day of the fourth month, the first day of the seventh month, and the first day of the tenth month.

**Days of the Solar and Lunar Phases**
The first day: dawn.
The fifteenth day: full moon.
Alternatively, the fourteenth or sixteenth day may also be used for morning observances.

**Days When the Supreme Great Dao Lord Ascends the Jade Radiance Chamber**
The fourth day of the first month, the eighth day of the second month, the fifteenth day of the third month, the eighth day of the fourth month, the ninth day of the fifth month, the sixth day of the sixth month, the seventh day of the seventh month, the eighth day of the eighth month, the ninth day of the ninth month, the fifteenth day of the tenth month, the third day of the eleventh month, and the twelfth day of the twelfth month.
On these days, the Supreme Great Dao Lord ascends the Jade Radiance Chamber to survey the four quarters of the world. Those of resolute aspiration who have forgotten their origins and wandered afar may, on these days at sunrise, face north and bow twice. They may also present their original vows within the oratory, swallowing saliva thirty-six times. It is also said that the Azure Lad of the Eastern Sea regularly ascends the Eastern Florescence Terrace on *dingmao* days to survey the four directions. On such days, facing the rising sun while performing this practice allows one to absorb solar essence.

**Days of Avoidance and Prohibition**
The ninth day of the third month, the second day of the sixth month, the sixth day of the ninth month, and the third day of the twelfth month.
On these days, one should enter the chamber and avoid contact with women. If the Six Corpses become disordered, they will stir the hidden blood, causing chaos and dissipation. The Three Spirits will lose their guard, the spirit will wither, and *qi* will depart, leading to death over time. Thus, these days are to be avoided—not merely to curb licentiousness, but to protect the women’s quarters.
The women’s quarters are in *shen*; the men’s quarters are in *yin*. *Yin* and *shen* mutually punish, and this punishment brings harm. On these days, the male and female Three Corpses emerge from the red pupils of the eyes: the female corpse beckons to the male, and the male corpse beckons to the female. Disaster and harm come and go, the spirit is lost, and purity is defiled. Though one may not perceive it, the signs manifest outwardly. The harm arises from the Three Corpses battling within the eyes, causing blood to flow into the Muddy Pellet.

On these days, even the most beloved concubine or cherished daughter-in-law must not face one another. My former master cultivated only this Dao and ascended as an immortal. Moreover, those who are not kin and lack intent—such as the immortal Liu Yao’s wife and daughter, who received this oral transmission—are no exception.

Another passage states: On *jiayin* and *gengshen* days, the corpse-spirits vie in chaos, and the spirit becomes restless and defiled. One must not share a mat with a spouse nor engage in conversation or meeting. Instead, maintain purity and vigilance, abstaining from all desires.

**Monthly Taboo Days**
- First month: second day, and *gengshen*.
- Second month: ninth day, and *xinhai* (some say *xinmao*).
- Third month: tenth day, and *jiaxu* or *gengxu*.
- Fourth month: first day, and *guihai*.
- Fifth month: eleventh day, and *renzi*.
- Sixth month: tenth day, and *guichou*.
- Seventh month: twelfth day, and *jiayin*.
- Eighth month: twelfth day, and *yimao*.
- Ninth month: thirteenth day, and *jiachen*.
- Tenth month: eighth day, and *dingsi*.
- Eleventh month: fifteenth day, and *bingwu*.
- Twelfth month: thirteenth day, and *dingwei* (some say *yiwei*).

The above days forbid incense-burning, though daily practice remains unrestricted.

**Emperor’s Execution Days**
*(Noted in small script above.)*

**Sacred Taboo Days**
- *Bingyin* and *dingmao*: Taboo for Daoist fathers.
- *Renchen* and *dingyou*: Taboo for Daoist mothers.
- *Bingshen* and *renxu*: Taboo for the Northern Emperor.
- *Wuchen* and *wuxu*: Taboo for the Southern Emperor.
- *Jue* days: One’s own fate-cutting day.
- *Suixing* days: The day governed by Jupiter in one’s year of birth.
- *Liuhai* days: The day opposing one’s own fate.
- *Yuehui* days: The last day of the lunar month.

On the above days, do not practice the Dao or burn incense.

**Days of Receiving Death**
- First month: *xu*.
- Second month: *chen*.
- Third month: *hai*.
- Fourth month: *si*.
- Fifth month: *zi*.
- Sixth month: *wu*.
- Seventh month: *chou*.
- Eighth month: *wei*.
- Ninth month: *yin*.
- Tenth month: *shen*.
- Eleventh month: *mao*.
- Twelfth month: *you*.

**Dragon-Tiger Days**
- First month: *si*.
- Second month: *hai*.
- Third month: *wu*.
- Fourth month: *zi*.
- Fifth month: *wei*.
- Sixth month: *chou*.
- Seventh month: *shen*.
- Eighth month: *yin*.
- Ninth month: *you*.
- Tenth month: *mao*.
- Eleventh month: *xu*.
- Twelfth month: *chen*.

**Selecting Hours by Monthly Governors**
Heavenly Stem, Great Unity, Victorious Light, Small Auspice, Transmission, Following Chief, River Chief, Ascending Brightness, Divine Marshal, Great Auspice, Merit Officer, Great Assault.

On yang days, begin with *Great Auspice* and proceed in order; on yin days, begin with *Small Auspice* and proceed in reverse. All commence from the earthly branch of the day.

**Void Days**
- *Jia* and *ji* days: *shen* and *you*.
- *Yi* and *geng* days: *wu* and *wei*.
- *Bing* and *xin* days: *chen* and *si*.
- *Ding* and *ren* days: *yin* and *mao*.
- *Wu* and *gui* days: *zi*, *chou*, *xu*, and *hai*.

**Hours of Heavenly Gate’s Opening and Closing**
On yang days: opens during yin hours, closes during yang hours. The six yang hours are *zi*, *yin*, *chen*, *wu*, *shen*, and *xu*.
On yin days: opens during yang hours, closes during yin hours. The six yin hours are *chou*, *mao*, *si*, *wei*, *you*, and *hai*.

The above hours are selected for submitting memorials when the gate is open.

According to ancient regulations, the days of fasting and taboos are scattered across scriptures and precepts, impossible to enumerate fully. Here, only those essential to practice are briefly listed. For setting up altars to pray for blessings, ascending the platform to initiate affairs, submitting memorials, confessing transgressions, or expressing gratitude, one may conduct rituals on these days. Even without supplications, using these guidelines to regulate conduct, eliminate wrongdoing, and reduce faults can aid cultivation. Matters one must not engage in, foods one must not consume, and actions that disturb the spirit or defile the body—how can these not be avoided?

If one abides in the realm of virtue and Dao, dwelling in the land of tranquility and emptiness, never forgetting even in dreams or haste, then every moment becomes a fast, and no day is bound by restrictions. Yet if one neglects self-cultivation, fails to regulate conduct, transgresses the registers of the Dao, and violates taboos, the Three Officials will examine and punish, the Five Emperors will censure faults, nine generations will share the guilt, and the individual will bear the consequences. The Dao is not unkind—beware of this.

**Four Grades of Fasting**
1. **Mind Fasting**: Diligently uphold the celestial precepts, aligning heart and intent, harmonizing inner and outer conduct. Without thought, desire, worry, or fear, sit in effortless forgetfulness. Virtue aligns with the perfected, and the Dao accords with the immortal standard.
2. **Regular Fasting**: Abstain from pungent foods and impurities, forsaking meat and desire.
3. **Pure Fasting**: Abstain from the five grains, sever worldly affairs, dwell in mountains and rivers, drink primordial *qi*, uphold precepts, forget sensory roots, dissolve the womb and placenta, and cut off friendships.
4. **Perpetual Fasting**: Uphold the above three fasts for one or two months, one or two years, or even twenty years—from initial resolve to ascension.

**Five Pungent Foods to Avoid**
Scallions, leeks, garlic, chives, and coriander.

According to *The Supreme Code of the Mysterious Capital’s Judgment of Sins*: Consuming the five pungent foods while reciting scriptures ranks as the foremost transgression among precepts. Cultivating and chanting while violating this offends the divine, defiles the sacred realm, and incurs the retribution of the "heart-piercing serpent hell." Generally, these foods are intensely pungent and foul; their odor lingers for days after consumption. Even in conversation, others find it repulsive—how much more so when facing the true and practicing the Dao? Additionally, foods resembling scallions, such as *xie* and *lei*, must also be avoided.

**Three Forbidden Meats**
- Wild geese: Heaven’s taboo.
- Dogs: Earth’s taboo.
- Carp, eels, and turtles: Water’s taboo.

The code states: Consuming the three taboo meats forever extinguishes the hope of immortality. Other creatures like eels and turtles, with their strong fishy odors, are also unsuitable. Furthermore, the meat of the six livestock, fowl, embryos, and eggs must not be eaten, as doing so harms life and severs destiny. Pork and dog meat are especially forbidden.

Not only does violating the precepts and prohibitions of the fast break one’s virtue and obstruct its fullness, but it also bars the gates of Heaven, preventing one’s memorials from ascending and one’s petitions from reaching the Supreme Mystery. Only in the case of illness may Daoist practitioners consume dairy, dried venison, elk, goose, duck, and dried fish—though even then, abstaining is preferable.

**Restrictions and Prohibitions**
The Master said: The essentials of the great Daoist law comprise three *ju* (stations), four *bao* (recompenses), seven *jin* (prohibitions), and five *ji* (taboos). If scholars observe these without transgression, they may enter the threshold of the Mystery Gate.

**Three Stations**
1. **Reciting incantations**: These are the secret words of High Heaven. The host of perfected beings and myriad spirits respond to the invocation and descend with the qi.
2. **Drawing talismans**: These are the celestial covenants of High Heaven. The host of perfected beings are summoned and descend.
3. **Performing rituals**: Those who preside over the bureaus of the immortal courts command their own hosts of perfected beings and spirits, each fulfilling their duties. They come when called and depart when sent, without need of talismans or incantations.

**Four Recompenses**
1. **Wisdom recompense**: Wisdom and insight grow daily.
2. **Spirit recompense**: The spirit becomes luminous and penetrating.
3. **Intent recompense**: The mind transcends the ordinary.
4. **Immortal recompense**: One attains the recompense of immortality.

**Seven Prohibitions**
1. **Prohibit the mouth**: If the mouth refrains from cursing, reviling, or speaking defiled words, incantations will communicate with the spirits.
2. **Prohibit the eyes**: If the eyes do not gaze upon filth or impurity, they may perceive the true spirits.
3. **Prohibit the ears**: If the ears do not listen to lewd sounds, they may hear the eight directions of wisdom.
4. **Prohibit the hands**: If the hands do not touch defiled objects, the mudras may connect with the divine.
5. **Prohibit the feet**: If the feet do not tread upon defiled or evil places, one may step upon the *gang* and ascend in flight.
6. **Prohibit the mind**: If the mind does not entertain defiled thoughts, it may summon and attract the true spirits.
7. **Prohibit the thoughts**: If thoughts do not arise in disorder, concentration may invoke the divine luminaries.

**Five Taboos**
1. **Avoid holding infants or nursing children**: This renders ritual power ineffective.
2. **Avoid frivolous conduct with women**: Such behavior often invites demonic interference.
3. **Avoid rage and defiance**: The divine and true spirits will only withdraw.
4. **Avoid partiality in merit**: Without impartial virtue, one’s name will not appear in the immortal registers.
5. **Avoid irreverence and doubt**: This allows the heterodox to mingle with the orthodox.

**Precepts and Prohibitions**
The Master said: In all fasting, purification, and audience rites with the perfected, one must follow the prescribed forms. At all times, one should examine and discipline one’s conduct, cultivating virtue and refining one’s nature. Only then may one’s sincerity ascend and communicate with the heavens. To indulge in delusion and transgression brings calamity upon the seven ancestors. Be ever vigilant.

**The Ten Supreme Precepts**
1. Maintain an impartial mind; do not deceive yourself.
2. Serve your lord and master with loyalty; honor heaven and earth, and revere your parents with filial piety.
3. Extend compassion and benevolence to all beings; live in frugality and temperance.
4. Maintain purity and uprightness; do not engage in factionalism.
5. Reverently follow the supreme Dao and deeply believe in self-cultivation.
6. Respect the spirits and gods; do not treat them with contempt.
7. In all clothing and sustenance, recognize the primordial ancestral *qi* of the Origin; do not entertain extraneous thoughts.
8. Use lye and water to cleanse impurities; do not indulge in adornment.
9. Recite with the mouth and prostrate with the heart; do not exhaust the body.
10. Enter the great stillness for seven days, and the divine radiance will become serene; thus, one may behold the Jade Pure Realm.

**The Twelve Great Precepts**
1. **The Virtue of Non-Killing**: Whether through mental intent, verbal suggestion, physical action, encouragement, instruction, or inducement, to cause the death of any sentient being is called killing.
2. **The Virtue of Non-Harm**: Secret plotting, slander, flattery, deceit, entrapment, cruel and unlawful methods—any act that harms sentient beings is called harm.
3. **The Virtue of Non-Envy**: Harboring resentment, scheming, exploiting circumstances to spread falsehoods, wishing misfortune upon others, devising means to seize their possessions—any act that envies and harms sentient beings is called envy.
4. **The Virtue of Non-Jealousy**: Secretly manipulating personal connections, desiring to surpass others, fantasizing about their appearance or possessions, scheming to remove or harm them—any act of resentment toward sentient beings is called jealousy.
5. **The Virtue of Non-Lust**: Whether through desire for beauty or wealth, impure intentions, illicit relations with kin, incestuous transgressions, or private infatuations—regardless of appearance, all such acts are called lust.
6. **The Virtue of Non-Stealing**: Breaching walls, altering marks, breaking seals, tampering with locks or signatures, concealing with private intent, borrowing without repayment, deceitful appropriation—all such acts are called stealing.
7. **The Virtue of Non-Greed**: Unrestrained desire, measuring the breadth of one’s capacity, coveting all things as if they were one’s own, insatiable craving, endlessly pursuing without regard for one’s allotted share—all such acts are called greed.
8. **The Virtue of Non-Desire**: The mind-monkey plays tricks, the intent-horse gallops wildly, the six senses churn, giving rise to the seven emotions; infatuation breeds attachment, and desire takes root—all such acts are called desire.
9. **The Virtue of Non-Hatred**: Partiality, attachment, discrimination between fragrance and stench, purity and filth, high and low, noble and base—failing to treat all equally is called hatred.
10. **The Virtue of Non-Deceit**: Doubtful hesitation, excess or deficiency, cunning and deceit, obstruction and frustration—all such acts are called deceit.
11. **The Virtue of Unadorned Speech**: Let words be free of embellishment.
12. **The Virtue of Harmonious Speech**: Let speech be free of malicious tones.

In practicing the Way of Great Stillness, one should observe the mind within stillness until the mind itself is forgotten—this is the true mind. Observe the form until form itself is forgotten—this is the true form. When both mind and form are forgotten, one naturally enters the formless Dao, which is the method of ascending in broad daylight.

**The Nine Wondrous Precepts of the Perfected**
1. Be respectful and yielding; honor and nurture your parents.
2. Be diligent and loyal to your lord and sovereign.
3. Do not kill; extend compassion to save all beings.
4. Do not commit lust; maintain integrity in conduct.
5. Do not steal; yield to righteousness and diminish the self.
6. Do not harbor anger; do not oppress others with fury.
7. Do not deceive; do not flatter, betray, or harm the virtuous.
8. Do not be arrogant; do not disdain the utmost truth.
9. Do not waver; uphold the precepts with single-minded devotion.

Those who wish to revere the supreme Dao, deliver the living, transcend the dead, subdue malevolent demons, and command the myriad spirits must receive the above precepts. First, one must surrender body and life to the Three Supreme Treasures, never following false teachers, deceptive influences, or the delusive and heretical teachings of demonic cults—nor engaging in practices akin to sorcery.

**Taking Refuge in the Three Treasures**
First, take refuge in the Supreme Treasure of the Dao.
Second, take refuge in the Supreme Treasure of the Scriptures.
Third, take refuge in the Supreme Treasure of the Masters.

The above precepts were all proclaimed by the Golden Mouth. If received without transgression, the heavens rejoice, all demonic trials are dispelled, and one attains the realization of flying immortality. Should one violate them, the Earth Bureau will report the offense, the Three Officials will investigate, and the Five Emperors will record the transgression. Minor offenses reduce one’s allotted lifespan; moderate offenses subject the living soul to examination; grave offenses forfeit merit and lead to retribution, shortening life and diminishing fortune, demoting one’s rank among the immortals. If the violation was not intentional, repentance is still permitted. However, after the Autumn Equinox offering, no further transgressions are forgiven. Should one again violate the precepts, there will be no absolution.

If one suddenly feels the spirit and mind distracted, the body heavy and feverish, the limbs oppressed and restless, or the senses dull and unsettled, one must immediately confess and repent. Threefold transgressions will not be pardoned. These are the precepts to be observed.

**The Dharma Gate of Liberation**

The Scripture states: The Dao of immortals values life and delivers boundless beings. Above, the Eight Gates are opened, and the celestial methods are transmitted—prohibitions of transgressions and blessings, karmic causes and conditions from past lives.

**The Eighteen Articles of the Gate of Transgressions:**
The body incurs calamity, which extends to nine generations of ancestors. One is bound to serve as a ghostly official, executed with metal and iron, subjected to the Great Heavenly Punishment of Jiutian, dismembered by the spirits of slaughter, beheaded a thousand thousand times, disfigured ten thousand ten thousand times. One falls into hell, bringing disaster to seven generations of ancestors—heads bound, self-destruction, bound and sent away, beheaded, fettered, forms constrained, spirits extinguished, eyes lost.

**The Sixty-Two Articles of the Gate of Blessings:**
The deaf regain hearing, the blind see clearly, the mute speak, the bedridden rise and walk, chronic illnesses are restored to health, white hair turns black, lost teeth regrow, the old become youthful and strong. All attain vitality, gold and jade manifest in form, withered bones become human again, and one’s full lifespan is preserved. True Persons recite the scriptures.

**The Sole Ascent to the Jade Capital**

This scripture is not transmitted to the lower world. It contains the secret celestial texts of the Upper Heavens, revered by all heavens. Its words are not of this mundane realm; it is conferred with oaths to the Ten Heavens and entrusted as a treasure of the Upper Heavens. Concealed within the Mystic Capital, its language is not of this world—transmitted but once in forty thousand kalpas, a chapter of natural spontaneity.

**The Gate of Precepts**
**The Precept Against Transforming Alien Bones into Kin.** Twelve Articles.
**Offering Gold and Treasures to Demonstrate Sincerity; Careless Leaking and Contempt.** Four Articles.
**The Practice of the Dao.** One Article.

**The Gate of Past Lives**
When a nation embraces the Dao with utmost sincerity, it flourishes through generations.

**The Gate of Causes and Conditions**
Those who honor, revere, and make offerings with devotion shall attain deliverance across lifetimes. Reverence and offerings create good causes and conditions.

**The Mystic Statutes and Regulations**
The Master said: "Merits and transgressions, sins and blessings—great ones alter lifespan, while minor ones hasten or prolong one’s years. There are three ranks and nine grades, all recorded in the Celestial Prohibitions of the Great Mystic Capital. All should adhere to them.

**Upper Rank, Upper Grade:** Removes and adds three *ji* (thirty-six years).
**Upper Rank, Middle Grade:** Removes and adds two *ji* (twenty-four years).
**Upper Rank, Lower Grade:** Removes and adds one *ji* (twelve years).
**Middle Rank, Upper Grade:** Removes and adds ten years.
**Middle Rank, Middle Grade:** Removes and adds nine years.
**Middle Rank, Lower Grade:** Removes and adds seven years.
**Lower Rank, Upper Grade:** Removes and adds half a *ji* (six years).
**Lower Rank, Middle Grade:** Removes and adds five years.
**Lower Rank, Lower Grade:** Removes and adds three years.

**Upper Rank, Upper Grade:** Reduces or increases two hundred and forty *suan* (years of fate).
**Upper Rank, Middle Grade:** Reduces or increases one hundred and twenty *suan*.
**Upper Rank, Lower Grade:** Reduces or increases one hundred *suan*.
**Middle Rank, Upper Grade:** Reduces or increases ninety *suan*.
**Middle Rank, Middle Grade:** Reduces or increases fifty *suan*.
**Middle Rank, Lower Grade:** Reduces or increases forty *suan*.
**Lower Rank, Upper Grade:** Reduces or increases thirty *suan*.
**Lower Rank, Middle Grade:** Reduces or increases twenty *suan*.
**Lower Rank, Lower Grade:** Reduces or increases ten *suan*.

The Master said: "For minor good and evil deeds, there are further reductions or increases, from ten *suan* down to one.

The Perfected of the Great Ultimate and Mystic Potential said: "One who cultivates upper-rank merits must not presume upon upper-rank, upper-grade transgressions.

For minor good deeds, ensure they are recorded daily.
For minor evil deeds, ensure they are dissolved daily.
Accumulate minor good deeds to form great merit;
Dissolve minor evils to achieve great goodness.
Upper-rank merits are difficult to cultivate;
Upper-grade transgressions are unforgivable.
Scholars who recite these shall enjoy mountains of blessings.
Those who disdain them shall suffer ten thousand kalpas of torment."

**Mystic Statutes, Upper Rank, Upper Grade**
Rebellion, treachery, defiance, and conspiracy.
The *Laws of the Mystic Capital* state: "Assassinating rulers or fathers, poisoning masters or elders, disrupting the moral principles of heaven, earth, and the Five Constants. Striking or defying rulers, masters, or parents; harboring anger, destruction, or betrayal toward masters, parents, or elders; abandoning rectitude for heresy; pledging faith to demonic sorcerers; committing incest with kin; colluding with the six relations; plotting murder—all such deeds erase one’s name from the registers of immortals, nullify merits, and ruin deeds. They burden nine generations of ancestors above, nine generations of descendants below, and oneself in the present, subjecting one to eternal trials by wind and blade. Unforgiven for ten thousand kalpas, one is reborn as a beast, never to receive human form again, forever barred from the hope of immortality. Lifespan is reduced by three *ji*."

**Upper Rank, Middle Grade**
Careless leaking, contempt, destruction, and plunder.
The *Laws of the Mystic Capital* state: "Disrespecting rulers, masters, or parents; the Three Treasures, sacred images, or divine texts; failing to observe time limits and recklessly divulging the Three Treasures, the Three Caverns’ secret scriptures, esoteric methods, registers, talismans, and diagrams; leaking the taboo names of heaven, earth, and the Five Agents; the unmanifested secrets of divine immortals, celestial mechanisms, and the taboos of fortune and misfortune; disrespecting rulers, masters, or parents; defiling or destroying the Three Treasures, sacred images, rulers, masters, parents, or any permanent property; assaulting, cursing, plotting harm, or murdering those who uphold the Dao, virtue, the Five Constants, or the six relations; sabotaging teachings; lacking faith; feigning devotion while slandering in secret, or professing loyalty while betraying in private; altering one’s resolve; seizing through force or deceit; plundering the sacred texts of the Three Treasures, rulers, masters, parents, or the belongings of the Seven Virtues—all such deeds erase one’s name from the ranks of immortals, nullify merits, and ruin deeds. They burden seven generations of ancestors, nine generations of descendants, and oneself in the present. Upon death, one enters eternal darkness, suffering the torments of the Three Wretched Realms. Unforgiven for a thousand kalpas, one is reborn as a loathsome insect, never to receive human form again. Lifespan is reduced by two *ji*."

**Upper Rank, Lower Grade**
Killing, debauchery, and theft.
The *Laws of the Mystic Capital* state: "Slaying all living beings, entrapping all sentient life; indulging in lust without restraint, engaging in improper conjugal relations; stealing all manner of things—all such deeds demote one’s immortal rank, nullify merits, and ruin deeds. They burden ancestors, descendants, and oneself in the present. Upon death, one sinks into hell, unforgiven even after three pardons. In this life, one bears the marks of blindness, deafness, muteness, madness, and incurable illness. Lifespan is reduced by one *ji*."

**Middle Rank, Upper Grade**
Breaking fasts, violating precepts, greed, jealousy, and hatred.
The *Laws of the Mystic Capital* state: "Consuming the five pungent vegetables, the three detestable meats, or excessive alcohol; deliberately craving the flesh of the six livestock, fowl, or insects; breaking fasts for private desires; eating impure foods; entering fasts with anger or joy; meting out rewards and punishments without restraint; deceitfully seeking food; insatiable in desires; restless and never content; envying those superior to oneself; resenting those inferior; despising the good; wishing others ill; harboring malice and hatred; unable to overcome others yet constantly scheming—all such deeds demote one’s immortal rank by three grades, nullify merits, and ruin deeds. Lifespan is reduced by nine years, fasts are suspended for six years, and one year is required to atone. One hundred and twenty merits are needed to redeem the sin."

**Middle Rank, Middle Grade**
Cunning, flattery, deceit, evil speech, and vulgarity.
The *Laws of the Mystic Capital* state: "A hundred crooked schemes, endless suspicions; acting on whims, flattering superiors while neglecting inferiors; momentary sycophancy, a hundred deceptions; false speech, roaring in anger; self-aggrandizement, abandoning rectitude for heresy; unable to discern truth from falsehood; favoring the crooked and despising the upright; nitpicking and dissecting; debating right and wrong, truth and falsehood; in movement, stillness, sitting, and lying—pursuing ostentation; unable to return to simplicity and plainness; defiling the purity of the Five Agents; engaging in impure, lewd speech and all manner of vulgarities; cursing and swearing at heaven, earth, wind, rain, the Five Agents, and spirits; uttering all manner of evil incantations—all such deeds demote one’s immortal rank by two grades, nullify merits, and ruin deeds. Lifespan is reduced by five years, and two hundred and forty *suan* are deducted. Two hundred days of fasts are suspended, and ninety merits are required to atone for the sin."

**Middle Grade, Lower Rank**
Stealing, deceiving, and obscuring the truth with intent toward all manner of evil.
*The Statutes of Xuandu* state: Secretly taking others’ belongings, refusing to repay debts, borrowing without returning, seizing opportunities to conceal, using cunning to claim lost items, turning public matters to private gain, feigning auspiciousness or refinement, taking what is superficial or substantial, passing off falsehood as truth, employing illusions to deceive, acting arrogantly toward gods and humans, deceiving both heart and spirits, indulging in secret misdeeds, obscuring the Three Luminaries, Heaven, Earth, and the virtuous—all such thoughts and intentions to commit evil demote one’s immortal rank by one grade, nullify merits, and ruin deeds. Lifespan is reduced by three years and one hundred twenty *suan* are deducted. One hundred days of fasts are suspended, and fifty merits are required to atone for the sin.

**Lower Grade, Upper Rank**
*The Statutes of Xuandu* state: Disdaining and wasting the Five Grains, discarding kindness and benevolence, breaking oaths and vows, defiling silk and cloth, lacking trust and righteousness, lacking benevolence and compassion, devoid of humility, without thoughts of rescue, making no firm promises, lacking harmony and affection—all such deeds demote one’s immortal rank by three grades, nullify merits, and ruin deeds. One year of fasts is suspended, seventy days of penance are required, and thirty merits are needed to atone for the sin.

**Lower Grade, Middle Rank**
*The Statutes of Xuandu* state: Disparaging the orphaned, impoverished, elderly, and young; failing to aid Daoist recluses in mountain forests or the cold-dwelling; neglecting to repair or complete unfinished meritorious works; refusing to assist the virtuous in times of illness, hunger, or need; destroying mountains and graves for personal comfort; using power to coerce; failing to save those in peril; felling thriving trees and plants; turning existence into nonexistence; deceiving others with obscured intentions; divining omens from Heaven, Earth, stars, and celestial anomalies; encroaching upon the authority of kings and nobles; using cunning to ensnare living beings; being remiss in service to superiors; failing in care for subordinates; appropriating incense and flowers for personal use; lacking devotion in cultivation—all such deeds demote one’s immortal rank by two grades, nullify merits, and ruin deeds for half a year. Fifty days of fasts are suspended, and twenty merits are required to atone for the sin.

**Lower Grade, Lower Rank**
*The Statutes of Xuandu* state: Falsely speaking in the name of celestial officials or divine spirits, fabricating one’s own virtue to seek blessings, intimidating the common folk, revealing the secrets of Daoist practices to gain recognition, altering seals, letters, talismans, or documents, prying into others’ private affairs, breaking seals or locks, recording minor transgressions, trampling or pressing down upon tiny creatures, cursing and humiliating the lowly, shouting while drunk, forcing labor upon the cold and hungry, making vows without fulfilling them, poisoning or destroying the Five Agents, stirring up disputes, indulging in refined foods, whipping and tormenting livestock, caging birds and insects, using impure incense and fire, performing rituals carelessly, conducting unclean jiao sacrifices, handling memorials and petitions with negligence, showing disrespect to superiors, violating ritual propriety—all such deeds demote one’s immortal rank by one grade, nullify merits, and ruin deeds for ninety days. One month of fasts is suspended, and ten merits are required to atone for the sin.

**Six Prohibitions for Cultivating the Dao**
Approaching corpses, attending funerals, visiting new mothers, places of execution, slaughterhouses, and houses of debauchery.

The above places must not be entered. As the *Oral Instructions of Li Shaojun* states: "Those who seek immortality as Daoists must not see the corpses of the dead, for this severely damages the spirit and qi. Only when a ruler, teacher, or parent’s love leaves no choice may one attend. Thus, when a Daoist passes away, they do not serve kings or lords—this would be lacking in loyalty. To dwell alone in solitude would be lacking in companionship. Only for one’s parents, teachers, or masters may one not avoid attending their funerals, expressing the utmost grief, sparing no injury to one’s own life. If one is harmed for this reason, it is no true harm. I keep this secret and transmit it orally."

The Supreme Lord’s *Hidden Way of Gazing at Life and Concealing the Court of Primordial Origin*:
On one’s natal day, face the direction of one’s natal sign, knock the teeth three times, and mentally perform two bows. Recite the incantation:
*"The Great One gathers life, the Three Blacks unite with the True. The embryo proclaims the Upper Radiance, the Mother is Mysterious, the Father is Primordial. They give birth to my five viscera, gather my spirit. Below, they irrigate with Jade Liquid; above, they ascend to the Muddy Pellet. At dusk, refine the seven po; at dawn, harmonize the three hun. On the right, the Jade Flower; on the left, the Golden Dawn’s whistle. Let me become a divine immortal, command spirits and employ gods. Ever preserve uprightness and integrity, soaring through the Ten Heavens."*
After the incantation, mentally bow to the four directions, knock the teeth three times, and swallow saliva three times. If practiced regularly, the hun and po will be guarded, and one will attain long life as a divine immortal.

Another method:
Those who study the Dao must first restrain the hun and po and eliminate the corpse-demons. On the days of the new and full moon, the days of *gengshen* and *jiayin*, purify oneself, enter the chamber, bathe to cleanse the dust, sit upright on the mat, and remain awake—this is the mark of true goodness. With cinnabar, mark beneath the left eye; with realgar, mark beneath the right nostril, letting a small portion enter the valley (the philtrum). Before marking, knock the teeth three times and recite the incantation:
*"The Upper Radiance flies and coils, cinnabar and yellow scatter like mist. Qi seizes the numinous and evil, corpse-filth sinks and vanishes. Harmonize the hun, refine the po, unite with the Great Spirit. Let me not die, live ten thousand years eternally □. Keen of sight and hearing, ever prosperous and upright."*
After the incantation, knock the teeth three times again and swallow saliva three times. With the second finger of the right hand, pinch the right nostril; with the second finger of the left hand, pinch beneath the right eye. Do this seven times each, pressing firmly without lifting the hands. These two places are the gateways through which the seven po and wandering corpses roam, the bridges by which essence-thieves and evil spirits cross. Thus, receiving the essence of cinnabar and realgar seals the path of corpse-demons, while the fragrance of the Two Radiance repels licentious chaos. This is the supreme method of the Great Ultimate. Regular practice harmonizes the hun and po, scatters corpse-filth, and leads to long life as a divine immortal with penetrating qi and clear vision. After three years of practice, lustful thoughts vanish. This is the method of the Supreme Numinous Perfected.

**Method for Purifying Filth**
Whenever one treads upon defiled or impure places, one must bathe to dissolve the contamination. Thus, the various methods of the Three Clarities and the descents of immortals include the *Refined Essence for Refining Corpses*. The method uses ten ounces of *xin* leaves and four ounces of peach branches (with the white bark peeled off), placed in a clean, empty vessel. Add one *hu* and two *dou* of clear water, boil until it rises once, then let it cool to a suitable temperature to bathe the body. All filth will be swept away, and it will also cure damp impediment, sores, and itching. Bamboo is hollow and white within; peach repels evil and breaks filth, thus dissolving the turbidity within the body. When heavenly beings descend, they never fail to use this method. As for the common world’s talismanic waters, incantations for rinsing, and minor arts of a *sheng* or *he*, none compare to this formula. If one prefers a milder version, simply refrain from using this water to wash the hair—it remains truly wondrous.

**Talisman of the Perfected Lady Wang of Purple Tenuity for Dispelling Filth**
This talisman is also called the *Talisman for Seizing Filth*. Carve it on a catalpa wood tablet, shaped like an audience tablet but slightly smaller. Keep it pure at all times. When consuming meat or treading upon filth, or when urgently performing rituals without time to bathe, first boil seven *ge* of *maoxiang* (sweetgrass) decoction, rinse the mouth, then dab seven drops on the palms of both hands. Rub the eyes with both hands and recite the incantation:
*"Accumulated filth follows the water’s flow, all departs through the divine intelligence. Swiftly, swiftly, as the statute decrees."*
Next, before the sacred altar, burn incense, knock the teeth forty-nine times, hold the tablet, and face the *Talisman for Seizing Filth* toward the mouth. Bow and exhale onto the talisman while reciting the incantation:
*"Filth departs, upright qi enters; upright qi abides, filth departs. The thirty-six aversions, the thirty-six filths—may the divine talisman seize them all. The Crimson Palace is serene and unified, the divine gate is bright and clear."*
After the incantation, set down the tablet, turn around, form the *Gedou* mudra, step the Dipper to the *gang* (celestial pivot), inhale a breath of qi, release the mudra, and proceed with the next step. This is an emergency method. If ascending the altar to present memorials, where the matter is more solemn, one must still follow the ritual of bathing.

**Method for Dispelling Childbirth Filth**
Generally, Daoists residing in jade palaces must avoid all childbirth entirely. For lay practitioners of the Dao, only the birth of a child cannot be avoided due to its moral significance. After a full month, one may dispel the filth and enter the oratory, following the previous methods. In all other cases, avoidance and abstention are required; violations will incur punishment.

**Temporary Leave for Attending Funerals**
Whenever a practitioner encounters a major funeral or the passing of parents or teachers, they must submit a report to the Three Heavenly Gates, sending a document to the attending officials. They must close the oratory and refrain from burning incense or performing rituals. If the matter is urgent and there is no time to draft a document, they may notify the attending officials, the Merit Officer, and the Local Earth God, submitting a petition to the Supreme Mystery. For major funerals, the mourning period is three years and twenty-seven months, not counting intercalary months—this is the system of mourning attire. Daoists only avoid the filth of corpses; once the body is encoffined and the filthy qi is blocked, after one hundred days, they may take temporary leave, dispel the filth, enter the oratory, and resume morning rituals while observing the mourning period for the full three years. □ The old ritual prescribed only one year of mourning, which does not conform to the limits of mourning attire and should not result in the neglect of morning rituals for an entire year. If the coffin has not been interred and one remains by its side, regardless of the time limit, one must not enter the oratory.

For one-year mourning, after one month, the filth-dispelling petition shall be submitted as prescribed.

For one-year mourning where one does not attend the corpse, as well as for nine-month mourning and below where one does not attend the corpse, after three days, one may take temporary leave, dispel the filth, and enter the oratory. Beyond the periods of one-year and nine-month mourning, one need not attend the corpse—avoidance is permissible.

Condolence visits must not be neglected; immediately after, one shall dispel the filth, bathe, and submit a report to the relevant authorities to resume the duties of the divine officers, all in accordance with standard ritual.

**Talisman for Encountering Filth When Entering or Exiting: Return to the Altar and Purify the Body**

Within the Cavern’s Profound Void,
Radiant shines the Supreme Mystery.
The Three Clarities’ Jade Decree illumines the Nine Crossroads,
The mighty spirits of the Eight Directions make me thus by nature.
The Numinous Treasure Talisman universally proclaims to the Nine Heavens:
*Qian-da-na, Dong-luo-gang, Supreme Mystery—*
Slay demons, bind evil, annihilate ten thousand ghosts.
The Central Mountain’s Original Beginning Divine Incantation, Jade Text:
Mystic water washes away filth, repels ghosts, and extends years.
Marching through the Five Peaks and Eight Seas, all take heed.
Demon kings bow their heads, guarding my chariot.
Malevolent filth is swept clean, the Dao’s qi ever abides.

Burn the talisman and recite the Jade Emperor’s Incantation:
Divine spirits, celestial perfected,
Royal fluid, profound nectar.
Upper Clarity’s Flowery Chamber,
Original Beginning, Venerable Lord.
Exquisitely entering the Great Radiance,
Illuminating the profound script.
Seven spirits, flying springs,
Receive smoke at Northern Feng.
I hold the rank of Upper King,
Repelling and uniting demon hordes.
Eight Mighties spew fire,
Reverently purifying your honored spirits.
Thousands upon thousands banish filth,
Malevolence no longer remains.
Myriad upon myriad demon kings,
Preserve life and protect the body.
Swiftly, swiftly, as decreed by statute and ordinance.

Recite the Jade Emperor’s Incantation thrice with the mudra, drawing the qi of the Heavenly Gate. For all altar constructions, sprinkle the altar twice in a circuit.

Whenever attending a mourning household and encountering defiling filth or childbirth, return to the altar and hastily inscribe this talisman. Burn it to ash, mix with pure water, infuse the water with the eastern qi, and consume it.

**Talisman for Ritual Purification and Bathing**

Supreme Numinous Water,
True qi flows unobstructed.
Yin and yang unite in clarity,
Divine candles illumine all sides.
Foul vapors purified,
The doomed and lifeless vanish.
The Three Corpses are stilled,
Longevity and eternal life arise—
The Dao harmonizes with the Perfected.

Recite the bathing incantation thrice, exhale thrice, and stir the water while reciting the stirring incantation:
Golden liquor, jade fluid,
Wash and cleanse the body’s form.
Mystic water purges filth,
Purifying the original spirit.
Seven numina guard and attend,
Myriad qi unfold in array.
Aspiring to purity and emptiness,
Manifesting the images of profound clarity.
Swiftly, swiftly, as decreed by statute and ordinance.

*Shangqing Lingbao Daofa*, Scroll Eight—End
*Shangqing Lingbao Daofa*, Scroll Nine

**The Rituals of the Nine Morning Repentance and Petition**

**Hair-Combing Incantation**
Mystic blossom of the Mud-Pill Palace,
Preserve essence and ensure its eternal abode.
Left, the Hidden Sun; right, the Root of the Moon.
The Six Harmonies refine and purify,
A hundred spirits receive grace.

Upon reciting this incantation, swallow saliva thrice. Comb the hair toward the auspicious direction. By practicing this regularly, hair will not fall. Comb frequently, taking many strokes without causing pain; one may also have an attendant comb the hair. Thus, blood and fluids flow unobstructed, and hair roots remain firm.

**Bathing Incantation**
Heaven and Earth unfold in clarity,
The Four Great Elements endure as constants.
Mystic water purifies filth,
Dispelling misfortune and ill omens.
Twin youths guard the gate,
Seven Perfected Ones settle in the chamber.
Divine fluid refines and washes,
Myriad qi merge in harmony.
Within and without, integrity is preserved,
Safeguarding this golden robe.

**Headgear and Sash Incantation**
Today is an auspicious and joyous day,
Aligning with the Emperor’s grace.
Dust and defilement are cleansed,
Corpse impurities sink and vanish.
Sins, grime, karmic obstacles—
Inside and out, all is purged and pure.
Inhaling the sun, absorbing the moon,
Treading the Nine Mornings.
Revolving around the Three Terraces,
Circulating through the Five Stars.
Adorning talismans and insignia,
Phoenix robes and tiger skirts.
Holding the profound scripture,
Chanting the numinous verses of the Cavernous Mystery.
Voices resound to the Great Empyrean,
The Five Emperors turn their chariots.
Bestowing upon me the feathered writ,
Ascending to the Supreme Clarity.

**Incantation for Consuming Elixirs and Medicinal Decoctions**
Reverently invoke the Five Elders of the Five Directions,
Summon the celestial physicians and officials of Bian Que,
Fifty each.
May this servant, upon consuming the medicine,
Be freed from illness,
And may illness depart from the body.
Riding the *kui* and mounting the *gang*,
Ascending through the Ten Heavens,
Counted among the Nine Earths,
Life and fortune flourish together,
Achieving immortality and never dying,
Merging with the Dao.

Upon reciting this incantation, face east and consume the medicine.

**General Conduct in Cultivating the Dao**
In practicing this Dao, recite the profound scriptures,
Conduct oneself with refined elegance,
And move in accordance with dignified ritual.
If one acts recklessly or crudely,
Ghosts and spirits will mock,
And the Three Offices will record transgressions,
Noting every deviation from the rules.
Thus, the precepts of fasting and abstinence are set forth for the adept.

To be called a Daoist,
One must adhere to the model of Daoists.
To be called a Perfected One,
One must conform to the standards of the Perfected—
How much more so for a disciple?

**Incantation Before Eating**
The hundred grains and five vermilions
Flow into the intestines and stomach.
The Five Viscera are at peace,
Corpse demons and evil perish.
The Seven Ancestors rest in tranquility,
Achieving long life and eternal vision.

Upon reciting this incantation, knock the teeth thirty-two times, swallow saliva nine times, and then eat.
One should eat before noon,
And avoid eating after the hour of *you*.
Before noon is the time when celestial beings eat;
After *you* is the time of demonic offerings.
Also, do not speak of death while eating,
Lest illness arise.
Do not leave food exposed for long,
Lest malevolent qi approach.
Thus, the Perfected Ones, in cutting off grains and entering the mountains,
Seek the essentials of ascending to immortality.

**Incantation Before Removing Clothes for Sleep**
Receive the mandate of the Great Emperor,
Ascend to the Nine Palaces.
A hundred spirits settle into their positions,
Arrayed to attend the Divine Lords.
Soul and spirit harmonize and refine,
The Five Viscera flourish in splendor.
The hundred limbs are infused with mystery,
The seven fluids brim with numinosity.
Fire and bells intertwine in radiance,
Exterminating ghosts and dispelling misfortune.
May the divine immortals above
Ever live without end.

Upon reciting this incantation, remove clothes and lie down.

**Incantation Before Sleeping**
Heaven has the Nine Stars,
Earth has the Nine Palaces.
The hundred joints of my body
Are accompanied by myriad spirits.
The Three Corpses hide in concealment,
The Five Viscera flow in circulation.
The Three Fields and four limbs
Move and rest in centeredness.
Dragon and Tiger, the Eight Trigrams,
Attend my jade countenance.
Ghosts, demons, and ten thousand spirits,
Do not disturb the true palace.

Knock the teeth twenty-four times, recite the incantation, and knock the teeth again as before.
When lying down, do not open the mouth,
Avoid sleeping on the back like a corpse,
Do not lend clothing, ritual robes, utensils, or vessels to others,
And do not practice qi absorption, guard the Three Ones, or recite profound scriptures—these are especially forbidden.

**Incantation for Knocking on the Door Before Entering the Latrine**
Left, the Spirit of Virtue; right, the Spirit of Purity.
On the left, the Earth-Controlling Lady;
On the right, the Six *Ding* dispel filth.
Remove my name from the register of the dead,
Inscribe my name in the register of the living.

Before entering the latrine, knock on the door three times. Upon reciting the incantation, knock the teeth three times. Do not spit, do not face north, do not look up at the Three Luminaries, and do not allow men and women to enter together—all these invite misfortune.

**Incantation Before Leaving the House**
Emerging from yin into yang,
The Four Paths open in clarity.
Eight spirits and Six *Ding*
Follow me in integrity and uprightness.
Sun and moon flank and assist,
My head bears the Seven Stars.

Knock the teeth seven times, visualize the Seven Stars upon the head, and let the *gang* star point forward.

**Method for Burning Incense**
Whenever entering the oratory to burn incense,
Focus the mind and concentrate the intention.
Visualize the incense smoke,
Do not look back upon exiting the door,
Nor turn to look behind.
When performing rituals, do not speak to others,
Keep the feet together when stepping over the threshold,
And do not hold the incense in the mouth.
Do not use hearth fire to burn incense,
Nor hearth ashes for incense residue—
These contain the dung of hidden dragons,
A great taboo in the Dao.

Instead, use pine or cypress branches and leaves,
Burn them to ash,
And store the ash in the incense burner.
Avoid using pungent vegetables, rank grasses,
Or materials infested with insects, fur, or shells,
Lest they defile the Supreme Perfected.

The Grand Immortal of the Supreme Ultimate often uses the ashes of willow, bamboo, pine, or cypress,
Mixed with mallow or hibiscus leaves and pounded into cakes,
With a small amount of spikenard added.
This mixture is free from impurities,
Burns well,
And lasts long without scattering ash.
Use more for a strong flame,
Less for a prolonged burn.

The Immortals often take ancient rattan roots,
Wash them in flowing water,
Dry them in the sun,
And pound them together with costus root and figwort.
Burning this dispels filth, conveys sincerity,
Summons the Perfected, and invites immortals.
Other pungent or acrid qi should not be used.

Incense must be burned with a strong flame,
So that the smoke rises in a single plume,
And sincerity ascends directly.
Do not let the smoke linger or scatter.
When reciting scriptures, the smoke may be continuous and unbroken.
The key is to hold the breath,
Silently pray with nasal exhalation,
And bow with controlled breathing.
In the principle of bowing with the heart,
Lest the Nine Palaces tilt,
One must align the body with the mind’s submission.

**For Receiving and Reciting Divine Scriptures, Seeking Forgiveness, and Praying for Blessings**
Perform incense rituals at midday during the Three Morning Audiences,
And during the Six Divine Hours of the Supreme Mystery.

The Three Morning Audiences occur at sunrise, midday, and sunset. The Six Divine Hours are midnight, dawn, mealtime, midday, late afternoon, and dusk—these being the six yang hours. If encountering *wuchen* or *wuxu* days, or during fierce winds, violent rain, or great thunder and lightning, one should temporarily cease and wait until the celestial *qi* settles before resuming morning cultivation.

**Entering the Oratory for Audience with the Origin**
The Master said: The oratory must be free from worldly filth and untouched by secular affairs. When establishing an altar, model it after heaven and earth, adapting to the household’s means and the dwelling’s size. Arrange the sacred ranks, face the imperial palace in reverence, maintain solemnity within and without, and purify both body and mind. Through steadfast gaze, commune with the perfected spirits; within the vast primordial chaos, unite with the supreme Dao. This is not merely an empty title to deceive the world.

In temples and monasteries, set up the positions of the Three Realms and the Most High Gods of the various heavens. If residing in a layman’s home, establish the Three Treasures at the center and array the host of immortals to the sides. During morning audiences, face the imperial palace in silent contemplation.

At dawn, calm the spirit and settle the mind. Don your cap and robes, then stand outside the door, visualize the gods of the body arrayed in order, strike the teeth nine times, and recite the incantation:

**Incantation:**
*"Great luminous spirit, ninefold verdant radiance,
Morning glow conceals its splendor, refining the five gods.
Palace chariots traverse the six directions, the seven spirits harmonized.
Knots unravel, brilliance scatters, the womb’s root purified.
Strike the teeth nine times."*

Enter the room, turn to the left of the earth’s gate, strike the teeth three times, and recite the secret incantation:

**Morning Entry Incantation:**
*"Four Brightnesses’ merit officers, messengers conveying truth,
Jade lads transmitting words, handmaidens of the oratory,
Convey my words to the altar’s true gods.
Primordial *qi* of the Upper Origin, descend and enter my body."*

After the incantation, form the Jade Clarity mudra, inhale the eastern *qi*, and visualize one merit officer, one messenger, two jade maidens, and one handmaiden of the oratory.

**Night Entry Incantation:**
*"Four Brightnesses’ merit officers, Dragon-Tiger messengers,
Primordial *qi* of the Orthodox Unity, handmaidens of the oratory.
For nighttime petitions, may all be illuminated.
Lads of the Upper Origin, maidens attend me.
Together we enter the altar hall, conveying my words,
That all may ascend and be heard."*

After the incantation, visualize one merit officer, two Dragon-Tiger messengers, one handmaiden of the oratory, one Illuminating Lad, and one Maiden of the Supreme Mystery—a total of six.

Upon entering, visualize the incense officials and messengers, the Two Lords of Dragon and Tiger, the Golden Lad attending incense, and the Jade Maiden transmitting words, flanking the incense table. The sun and moon stand nine inches from the face, the Northern Dipper crowns the head, the *piao* star faces forward, and the three *qi* billow thickly, enveloping the body.

Then hold the breath, settle the spirit, bow with the heart toward the mat, or hold the tablet and bow three times. Strike the teeth nine times and recite the secret incantation:

**Incantation:**
*"Mysterious true Seven Stars, august lords of the luminous soul,
Radiance flows inward, permeating the Dipper’s spirit.
The Three Terraces gleam, the seven fluids entwine.
The golden register guards the tiger, defending the gate of life.
Divine transformation pervades the numinous, the Purple Court governs the wheel."*

After the incantation, present your intentions with focused sincerity. The Nine Gods will descend to the imperial seat, and resonance will surely be attained.

**Silent Memorial:**
*"Your humble servant [Name], in his appointed rank, respectfully memorializes the sacred ranks."*

Deep in my thoughts, I recall how I early entered the Mystic Pass and gained audience with the wondrous Dao. Ashamed that I lack the Ten Virtues to aid the Six Penetrations, I have failed to stir the numinous powers to gratitude and, in my actions, lightly transgressed the precepts. My efforts begin with zeal but end in slackness; my words align with my heart in appearance but not in truth. My conduct is flawed, my burning of incense and cultivation lack discipline. I fear that the Six Palaces will inscribe my transgressions in their luminous records, and the Three Corpses will secretly memorialize my faults and offenses.

On this auspicious day, I humbly offer repentance and gratitude, praying that you will take pity on my ignorance and specially grant me absolution. May the profound merit accumulate through three thousand deeds, and the elixir swiftly reach completion through nine refinements. May the celestial bureaus record my goodness, and the registers of the dead erase my misfortunes. May I obtain the Golden Writ of the Eight Effulgences to refine my qi and cultivate the true, and the Jade Script of the Five Texts to attain the power of long life and enduring vision. May the Dharma remain peaceful, calamities and declines be washed away, the myriad spirits be subdued, and the hordes of demons not intrude. May I establish merit in propagating the teachings and guide the people to support the world. Above, I repay the virtue of my sovereign, teachers, and parents; below, I succor the spirits of the unseen and the stagnant. May the true Dao endure forever, and both form and spirit attain perfection.

I, your humble servant, am overwhelmed with trepidation and awe. Thus, I respectfully speak.

**Morning Departure Incantation:**
*"Emerging from yin into yang, the myriad spirits open the way."*

When the memorial is complete, request the closure of the Yellow Chamber. The Jade Maidens attend in stillness, fully prepared within the numinous palace.

**Night Departure Incantation:**
*"Mysterious and supreme, the Great Yin; the eight windows open with clarity. What has been presented is conveyed by the Maiden of the Way. When the matter is complete and all return to their positions, the myriad spirits withdraw in tranquility."*

After the incantation, depart from the chamber. Within the oratory, sit and concentrate, recalling the practices and secret methods you have mastered in daily cultivation—this is especially excellent. If integrating other methods with their own rituals, follow the original procedures.

**Repentance and Atonement for Transgressions**
The essence of cultivating the true lies first in minimizing faults. If one does not reform from transgressions, the Dao remains distant. Even if one’s practice has not yet ascended to the highest stages of the Way, if conduct is unchecked, how can one subdue ghosts and spirits? How much less can one present memorials, bow in reverence, and deliver the unseen and the manifest? The bureaus of merit and transgression miss nothing, not even the slightest detail.

Xu Yuanzhen of the Jin dynasty retreated into the mountains and forests, diligently cultivating the Dao with wholehearted devotion. Gradually, he entered the ranks of the true, yet the Three Officials dispatched Zhou Fang and others to present him with the vermilion tablets of his transgressions, saying: *"Those who aspire to study the Dao and long for life, who are registered among the immortals, whose profound hearts dwell in the distant, and who revere the lofty spirits, must first attain worldly merit, avoid entanglement in misfortune, let hidden virtue take root, and let benevolence ascend. Only then may they ascend to the true and seek immortality, their names recorded in the Azure Palace."*

From this, it is clear that those who have not yet reached Xu Yuanzhen’s level must surely recognize the need to minimize faults and cultivate themselves. In upholding the Dharma and practicing the teachings, in seeking immortality and studying the Dao, one must repent past transgressions and accumulate future merit.

Thus, the *Treatise on the Mystic Principles* states: *"To correct a fault and not repeat it is merit; to establish a practice and not grow weary is called daily renewing one’s virtue. Heaven will bless such a one."* If one merely speaks of prayer and gratitude while the heart remains unexamined, repeating past transgressions in future actions, adorning the exterior while corrupting the interior, then one’s efforts—whether gazing at the stars, bowing to the moon, observing fasts, upholding precepts, burning incense, or reciting scriptures—will be in vain.

Some boast grand words to deceive the world, claiming that if sins are not accumulated and evil not committed, there is no need for repentance or adherence to the teachings. Such extreme and forced rhetoric, whether excessive or insufficient, is not the Middle Way. One should repent wholeheartedly, recognize faults with certainty, follow the scriptures and teachings, and practice according to the established formats. Thus, one may erase the records of transgressions from the bureaus of the Three Officials and the Five Emperors, and inscribe one’s name in the realms of the Ten Poles and Nine Empyreans. By establishing merit without slackness, ascending in immortal flight is assured. There is no self-obstruction; those with aspiration often succeed.

**Rite of Atonement**
Except for the day after the Autumn Equinox, regularly perform this rite on the Three Primes, the Eight Festivals, one’s birthday, the days of *jiǎzǐ* and *gēngshēn*, and other auspicious occasions. Enter the oratory or a pure place in a temple, mountain, or marsh. Burn incense and single-mindedly reflect on past faults.

First, sit silently beside the altar, deeply contemplating all actions and transgressions. Trembling with reverence, rise, adjust your attire, and compose your bearing. Ascend the altar, make your declaration, and perform the ritual. Enter the chamber, recite the incantation, and offer incense according to the proper method. Follow the usual audience rites: in the morning, begin with the East; at noon, with the South; at night, with the North. Perform repentance and atonement for the five directions, adhering to the established ritual format.

After the third offering of incense, bow according to the natural audience protocol. This matter values secrecy, and solitary practice is preferred over complexity. Thus, only the texts for atonement in the four directions are compiled here, with adjustments made as needed.

**Burning Incense and Making Offerings**
The Nine Pure Upper Saints and the myriad spirits of the Three Realms, grant your assent to my words.

On this auspicious day, I purify my heart, repent my transgressions, and bow in prayer for grace. First, I extend my wishes for the imperial dynasty, the altars of soil and grain, the ancestral spirits, and the luminous chariots of the Nine Empyreans, that they bestow blessings for ten thousand generations.

May the present emperor’s foundation endure forever, his reign prosper and flourish. May his sacred longevity parallel heaven and earth, and his virtue and teachings equal creation. May all directions turn toward goodness, the hundred grains ripen in abundance, and all beings with awareness and knowledge awaken to the true Dao. May all, without limit or boundary, ascend together to the realm of glory and joy. May the great transformation flourish, and the true Dharma never decline.

I dare to express my humble wishes, reverently addressing the imperial majesty.

I, your humble servant, am overwhelmed with trepidation and awe. Thus, I respectfully speak.
