Highest Clarity Dharma-Enforcing Perfected Stewards.
Jade Clarity Dharma-Enforcing Perfected Stewards.

The above ten ranks require ninety rectifications of corruption to enter the Immortal Steward ranks, one hundred to enter Upper Immortal, and one hundred twenty to enter Perfected Steward. Gradually, one enters the ranks of Perfected Ones, all specially conferred by the Celestial Emperor. Concurrently, all heavenly, earthly, and aquatic immortal offices are also specially conferred. Next, one enters the inner ministries of the Heavenly Mechanism, the Heavenly Mechanism General Ministry, and the Grand Mystery General Ministry.

For each rectification of corruption, a memorial must be submitted to the Heavenly Ministries, where it is examined by demon officials. If not verified by the Demon Bureau, the merit of numinous demons is assessed. The Demon-Restraining Bureau recommends, and the Three Officials and Five Emperors memorialize to the various heavens. Only after a formal report is made can one ascend in rank; demotion follows the same procedure.

Without penetrating the hundred spirits and achieving spiritual communion with the heavenly bureaus, the mysteries cannot be fully understood. There are separate celestial immortal ranks and divine courts where golden tablets are issued daily from the Jade Capital. Only after being granted robes, establishing a residence, paying homage to the Primordial, receiving the Dipper’s scriptures, and inspecting the grotto-vision—with the great stabilization of the seven scriptures’ merit complete—can one fully comprehend the supreme mysteries of the Highest Mystery.

**Discourse on the Testing and Recording of Offices and Ranks**

It is said: The scriptural records of the Three Caverns are transmitted in accordance with the cosmic rhythm. Thus, the *Dongzhen* section has the *Shangqing Grand Grotto Returning Chariot to Complete the Dao Record*, one rank. Those who wear it are called Disciples of the Grand Grotto of Highest Clarity. If one does not wear the record but enters the chamber to recite the *Grand Grotto Scripture* and practices its great functions, one is only addressed as "Minor Servant So-and-So."

The *Thirty-Nine Chapters of the Grand Grotto* belong to the *Dongzhen* section, not to be confused with those who mistakenly refer to passages from the *Scripture of Salvation* as the *Dongjing*. Moreover, the original ranks and petitions of the Grand Grotto’s fundamental system were established in primordial antiquity; it was only in later ages that people began compiling the *Grand Grotto* methods, though these ultimately diverge from the ancient texts.

The *Dongshen* section flourished during the Eastern Han, where all ranks below the *Mengwei Record*—along with miscellaneous registers—were consolidated under the *Zhengyi* Altar. The *Tianxin* and *Wulei* methods, as well as talismanic and prohibitive arts, were all subsumed within it. This need not be elaborated further.

Within the *Dongxuan* section, there is the *Zhongmeng Secret Record of the Numinous Treasure*, followed by the *Zixu Yangguang Record*, with only the *Great Method of the Numinous Treasure* attached to it. Those who wear the record but do not practice are merely called "Record Ranks." Once one has performed the *Great Method of the Numinous Treasure*, and the ritual methods derive from it, one inevitably engages with the world and interacts with beings, adapting rites to circumstances. Thus, ranks emerge, and names are reluctantly assigned to align with the demands of the age. When memorials are presented and petitions submitted, their *qi* is unified; when deliverance is extended to the hidden and manifest, titles are conferred accordingly. If one’s practice contradicts the record, one risks becoming a laughingstock among spirits and gods.

Lin Shichen once said: "Thus, five ranks of immortal offices are established to facilitate their application." From this foundation, one cultivates without cease, accumulating merit and refining *qi*, merging with the Dao and attaining spirithood. Good deeds resound in the Mystic Capital, immortal names are inscribed in the Golden Towers, and heaven bestows true offices upon the world. These are tasked with propagating the Dao and transforming the age, bestowing feathered canopies upon the azure heavens. When summoned to ascend, their affairs align with past and present—such outcomes arise from virtue, not from presumptuously claiming lofty ranks and grand titles.

Some practice the scriptures and methods of the *Numinous Treasure* yet seek divergent paths; others perform the *Pure Brightness* method to supplement alternate ranks—both are incorrect. All should wear the *Zhongmeng Record* and fulfill their original office.

As for the previously mentioned *Tai Shang* Enforcer, who heads the ranks, this office indeed exists. However, *Tai Shang* refers to the spirit of the Primordial Void. It is also said that *Tai Shang* denotes the utmost greatness, while *Shang* signifies supreme reverence. It is further said that beyond the utmost greatness and unfathomable height lies the *Tai Shang*. It is also said that nothing surpasses the *Tai Shang*. Thus, the Dao is called the *Tai Shang Yuanji Great Dao*; beyond this, the term *Tai Shang* should not be applied. In Daoist scriptures, it may stand alone as a title of the utmost honor, akin to the most exalted of worldly designations. Can a ruler’s title be appropriated for a subject’s rank? In the secular realm, all official ranks from the first grade upward derive from the sovereign; would one prefix a title with "Emperor So-and-So" or "Son of Heaven Such-and-Such"? Moreover, the opening of register scrolls from the ancestral altars all bear the title *Tai Shang So-and-So Record*, for the talismans within originate from the *Tai Shang*. When practitioners issue talismanic decrees, they are called *Tai Shang So-and-So Talisman*—this is appropriate for talismans and records but not for ranks and titles. Since records derive from the *Tai Shang*, and ranks are based on records, one cannot prefix *Tai Shang* to a title. Thus, *Tai Shang Enforcer Perfected* is somewhat incongruous.

In secular memorials, terms like "Ancestral Temple" or "Emperor" are centered and set apart. Official ranks of ministers may include "Before the Throne" or palace names, with a space left blank, yet none prefix their titles with "Emperor" or "Son of Heaven." How can one presume to prefix *Tai Shang* to a rank? Would this bring you peace?

A rank is the position one attains. To be called *Disciple of Such-and-Such Record* or *Officer of Such-and-Such Method* means one wears this record and practices this method—one cannot claim *Tai Shang* as one’s own title.

Some argue that the *Southern Bureau Enforcer* is a title for those who practice the scriptural methods, and that other *Numinous Treasure* methods do not use the *Southern Bureau* designation. Yet they fail to recognize that the scriptural methods are the foundational practice. Today, in ritual and offering halls, when issuing talismanic decrees, bestowing true certificates, or enacting canonical protocols, all derive from the scriptural methods. Those ignorant of their origins mistakenly claim that the *Numinous Treasure* methods used in worldly rituals differ from the scriptural methods—how shallow their understanding!

Since the inception of the *Numinous Treasure* methods, the original rank of *Tai Shang Enforcer* has never been adopted by discerning scholars across the realm. Recently, some have taken titles like *Lineage Master*, *Enforcer Perfected Administrator*, or falsely established "retreat names" as designations—are these not delusory and presumptuous?

In recent times, the scriptural methods have proliferated ranks, such as the eight grades of immortal offices, six categories of martial ranks, and various hierarchical arrangements—these have grown increasingly elaborate and should not be cited or employed. One cannot, simply because they are recorded in the scriptural methods, casually assume and confuse the celestial order.

Some call themselves *Disciples of the Numinous Treasure Zhongmeng* and claim to practice the *Great Method of the Numinous Treasure*. If one does not thoroughly understand the *Zhongmeng*, then the *Numinous Treasure Record* is irrelevant. The *Southern Bureau Enforcer* is an ancient office of the *Numinous Treasure*; the Highest Heavenly Emperor is well aware of this. To wear this record and assume this office is to rightfully perform its duties—no further petitions to the ranks are necessary. This is a rigid and unyielding view.

Thus, the revered master bestowed the four ranks of the *Southern Bureau*, each prefixed with "Immortal," yet still deemed them unworthy. He then petitioned the Supreme Mystery to specially designate the *Dianzhe* as the first rank. Moreover, the *Dianzhe* office exists in other methods, though it was not previously established in the *Numinous Treasure* tradition. The four ranks cannot be abolished, as they await those who attain perfection and achieve the Dao.

**Five Ranks of the Southern Bureau**
*Southern Bureau Enforcer Dianzhe*
*Southern Bureau Enforcer Immortal Officer*
*Southern Bureau Enforcer Immortal Official*
*Southern Bureau Enforcer Perfected*
*Southern Bureau Enforcer Perfected Official*

*Seal Scripts, Regulations, and Standards*

The discussion turns to the proper seals for this method. The Master states: A seal is a token of trust. Its use lies in sealing objects and documents, serving as the credential of those who govern. *The Han Officials’ Etiquette* states: Kings and marquises use *xi* (imperial seals), while nobles from the rank of marquis to officials of the middle second grade use *zhang* (seals); all others use *yin* (ordinary seals). These are the seals of the mundane world.

In the flourishing age of high antiquity, humans and spirits each remained in their proper places, and yin and yang did not transgress their bounds. Thus, the application of the Dao was seen only in the cultivation of truth and refinement of the fundamental, leading to lightness of body and ascension in flight. From the middle antiquity onward, reverence for the true declined daily, the orthodox Dao grew obscure, and deceit and falsehood ran rampant. High and low were overturned, and so methods were introduced to remedy these ills: manifestos to convey sincerity, and seals bestowed as tokens of trust. Thus, the meaning of using seals became nearly identical to worldly conventions—an adaptation of the Dao’s workings to the exigencies of the times.

However, those whose titles resemble those of mundane offices must not employ the same graphs; those who borrow ordinary seal scripts must not use them in bureau affairs; those who presume to encroach upon the offices of the celestial perfected must not employ them beyond their proper rank; and those who indulge in excessive complexity must not invoke the great methods of the *Numinous Treasure*. Since ancient times, only the seal of the *Southern Bureau under the Three Heavens’ Gate* has been used. In recent times, as authentic seal scripts have become scarce, and the four characters “under the Three Heavens’ Gate” are not to be used in the human world, omitting them would render the seal incomplete. Therefore, in accordance with this method, only the seal of the *Numinous Treasure Great Method Bureau* is employed.

Now that one has advanced to the rank of *Dongxuan* and bears the *Middle Alliance Register*, practicing the *Numinous Treasure* method, one’s office carries great weight. Apart from memorials submitted in worship, all documents—whether upward petitions, downward official communications, notices, proclamations, talismans, or records—addressed to the bureaus of the Three Realms and the Ten Directions, the netherworld offices of the Nine Provinces and Four Seas, the cavern-heavens of the Nine Earths’ profound yin, or the celestial and terrestrial administrations under their jurisdiction—must bear the seal of the *Numinous Treasure Great Method Bureau*, for it is the true token of the Enforcer’s authority. How could any other seal suffice? All formal documents and their envelopes must uniformly employ this seal. Only memorials and their cases may use the *General Memorial Seal*. When dispatching official notices or documents, the seal of one’s own office is used.

**On the Seal of the Numinous Treasure Great Method Bureau**
From the Zhou and Qin dynasties to the present, measurements have varied. There are the Zhou foot, the millet foot, the Han foot, the Later Zhou foot, and in the present dynasty, the cloth-and-silk foot and the provincial foot. In the Jiang-Huai region, there is the Huai foot—each differing in length. The seal of the Enforcer of this method should measure two *cun* and five *fen* in diameter, according to the Zhou foot. Often, method texts specify seal diameters in *cun* and *fen* without clarifying the length of the foot. Later scholars who seek to emulate antiquity may uniformly adopt the Zhou foot.

**On the General Memorial Seal**

**On the Ranks of the Cavernous Perfection and the Dao of Jade Purity**
The teachings of the Cavernous Perfection (Dongzhen) and the Dao of Jade Purity (Yuqing) emerged during the Jin dynasty’s Yonghe era through the Seven Perfected—Three Mao, Two Xu, and Yang Jiang—who transmitted the formats for memorials and petitions to the celestial courts. The teachings of the Cavernous Mystery (Dongxuan) and the Numinous Treasure (Lingbao) trace back to the era of the Three Sovereigns and the Kalpa of Crimson Clarity, where such practices were already established. The formats for memorials and petitions derive from the *Scripture of the Five Refinements for Animating the Corpse* and the *Original Conduct of the Five Elders*. As the Jade Dawn (Yuchen) was a disciple of the Primordial Beginning (Yuanshi), this seal serves to convey sincerity to the ancestral masters. Those not ordained in this method may not borrow its use.

When performing the memorial rites of the Cavernous Mystery, two sheets of paper are affixed before and after the petition, inscribed with talismans according to the prescribed form. The Orthodox Unity (Zhengyi) memorial seals and the Twelve Minor Seals are not employed; only the *General Memorial Seal* is used above the date. The seal’s inscription reads: *"Triple Heaven’s Covenant of Unification"*—a text also found in the *Divine Empyrean Registers*. Later generations, seeing this seal recorded therein, have mistakenly attributed it to the Jade Purity and the Cavernous Perfection department. Yet before the rise of the Divine Empyrean teachings, the Cavernous Mystery memorial rites of the Five Dynasties and earlier all employed this seal. It is, in fact, the text of the *Lingbao Great Charter for Ascending to Heaven*, albeit with its lower portion omitted. The living use it as proof when submitting memorials to the celestial courts.

When the *General Memorial Seal* is used for Cavernous Mystery petitions, it remains part of the original Numinous Treasure canon. Moreover, the *Great Charter for Ascending to Heaven* has always belonged to the Cavernous Mystery department. When issued to the deceased, the characters *"Summon the Soul"* are added beneath the *"Ninefold Mystery Envoys"*. For the living, the lower portion is omitted. How, then, could it be claimed as belonging to the Cavernous Perfection? The Divine Empyrean encompasses the myriad methods of the Celestial Altar, all fundamentally rooted in the Numinous Treasure. Its three talismans are also included in the registers for practical use, yet nowhere is this seal designated as unrelated to the Cavernous Mystery.

In the present dynasty, the Daoist master Wang Shengqing recompiled the *Great Methods of the Numinous Treasure*, adhering to the ancient methods of Master Chen and other traditions, which many have since followed. The original seal measured two *cun* and four *fen* in diameter by the Zhou foot. If the *Seal of the Enforcer* employs the Zhou foot, this seal should likewise follow the Zhou foot; if the cloth-and-silk foot is used, it should match accordingly. Deviating from the ancient foot risks censure by the Three Officials.

**On the Nine Elders of the Immortal Capital Seal**
The Dao of the Grand Purity and Orthodox Unity was bestowed by the Mysterious Origin and Later Sage upon the Orthodox Unity Celestial Master, complete with rites for submitting memorials. The *Nine Elders of the Immortal Capital Seal* is used because the Grand Purity shares its origins with the Eight Elders, who revere the Most High as their master. Thus, when disciples petition their master, they bow twice at the beginning of the memorial, affixing the *Nine Elders of the Immortal Capital Seal*, and conclude with the *Twelve Minor Seals* at the *"Year of the Great Yin"* section.

**The Twelve Minor Seals**
- *Bow Twice*
- *To the Jade August One*
- *For Your Attention* (placed to the side)
- *Beginning of the Memorial*
- *To the Grand Purity* (top)
- *End of the Memorial*
- *Your Servant [Surname]*
- *To the Grand Purity* (side)
- *Year of the Great Yin*
- *Mystic Capital*
- *For Your Attention*
- *Waist Seal*

Each of the twelve seals measures one *cun* and two *fen* in length, eight *fen* in width, with thickness unrestricted.

**On the Yellow Spirit Transcendent Memorial Seal**
The *Essentials of Orthodox Unity* records a single seal named the *Yellow Spirit Transcendent Memorial*, slightly larger in diameter, used primarily for emitting *qi* to treat illnesses. According to the present standard, it measures one *cun* and eight *fen* in diameter by the Zhou foot. Following ancient script, two seals are used for urgent petitions to the Celestial Emperor when the formal memorial is not prostrated.

**Dao Lord’s Jade Seal**
This seal is employed in transmitting the Dao, receiving teachings, and seeking investiture. Ancestral masters use it in their memorials.

**Crimson Seal of the Chaotic Abyss** | **Jade-Character Crimson Script Seal** | **Eight Might Dragon Script Seal**
The preceding three seals are used universally for imprinting talismans, swallowing, wearing, or affixing for protection.

**Middle Section of the Numinous Script Seal**
This seal is used to disseminate the true script and safeguard mountains, rivers, lands, and waters.

**Primordial Beginning’s Mandate Seal**
This seal imprints the yellow registers and white tablets for the Primordial Beginning’s mandates.

**Seal of the Three Heavens and the Most High**
This seal serves as the contract of the central alliance and the general memorial of the Numinous Treasure. It may be used universally for submitting petitions, decrees, memorials, and dispatches, as well as for imprinting talismans, treating illnesses, and expelling malevolent forces. It measures two *cun* and seven *fen* in length and three *cun* and four *fen* in width.

**Seal of the Numinous Treasure Mystic Altar** | **Jade Memorial of the Three Flying Mystic Qi** | **Seal for Dispatching the Nine Spirits’ Flying Petitions** | **Seal of the Great Mystic Capital Province** | **Seal of the Grand Marshal Overseer** | **Divine Tiger Virile Left Seal** | **Divine Tiger Feminine Right Seal** | **General Command Seal** | **Thorn Chamber Seal**

**On the Use of Seals**

It must be stated that the Dao of the Numinous Treasure emerges from before the Ultimate Non-Being, while its methods arose only after the Middle Antiquity. When Master Ge of Eastern Wu received the scriptures from the Perfected Xu Laile, the methods were still incomplete. During the Jin dynasty, Xu Jianyang encountered the Divine Mother Chen, who transmitted the teachings of the Filial Dao Bright King of the Lunar Palace, and only then did the regulations and ranks become manifest. The present designation of the "Pure Brightness Abbey" is incorrect, for the Numinous Treasure admits no dual Dao.

By the end of the Jin and Song dynasties, fasting and cultivation had flourished, and documents and dispatches had grown increasingly numerous—thus, seal scripts became indispensable. The Celestial Master of Han employed only the *Yangping Governance Unity Seal* to achieve ascension. Xu Jianyang, having received the *Bronze Talisman and Iron Charter* and the *Golden Elixir Treasured Scripture*, along with the teachings of the Filial Dao Bright King, followed the Dao of the Numinous Treasure, which likewise did not require many seals. Yet through these, he elevated his entire household to transcendence and took his place among the lofty heavens. Even among those perfected adepts and exalted immortals who attained the Dao, some did not rely on seals to benefit the world and bring peace to the age. Thus, the weight of the method does not lie in the number of seals.

Later practitioners, however, fell short of the profound mysteries of the ancients, and their seals multiplied a hundredfold. In recent times, those performing Numinous Treasure rites often do not use the seals of their proper offices for memorials and documents, instead employing the *Jade Memorial of the Three Flying Mystic Qi* to dispatch them—a practice never seen in the ancient methods of the Numinous Treasure. Moreover, in the issuance of talismans and proclamations, they use the *Seal of the Three Heavens and the Most High*. Yet the descent of talismanic script originates from the Supreme Mystery; when inscribed by human hands and presented to heaven for enactment, it suffices. There is no need to append official titles to the talisman’s end, for what role does the *Three Heavens and the Most High* play therein? The Three Heavens and the Most High are not to be used as seal inscriptions.

Furthermore, the method includes a *Jade Seal of the Dao Lord*, which is also improper. In the secular realm, the Son of Heaven and feudal lords use the term *xi* (imperial seal), so for the Dao Lord to be called a *seal* is inappropriate. Jade seals are termed *jade xi*; for instance, the ancient Son of Heaven possessed eight *xi*, and the Qin dynasty’s Li Si inscribed the *Transmitted Treasure of the Realm* with the words, *"The August Emperor receives the Mandate; may his prosperity endure for ten thousand generations."* The imperial seal transmitted by the sagely dynasty bears the inscription, *"The Emperor reverently receives the Heavenly Mandate’s Treasure."* Even the Celestial Master’s jade seal is simply called the *Yangping Governance Merit Seal*. From antiquity to the present, no one has ever self-styled a *jade seal* within the seal’s inscription. The Dao Lord is the ruler of the celestial center, akin to the Son of Heaven in the mortal realm—how could his ministers presume to use his seal? Moreover, when ministers submit memorials to their sovereign, would they dare to affix the sovereign’s seal? Such a thing is unthinkable.

Additionally, seals such as the *Crimson Script of the Primal Chaos Seal*, the *Numinous Writ Central Scroll Seal*, and the *Eight Might Dragon Script Seals*—and others of their kind—all take four characters from the scriptures as a single seal. For example, *"Severely Command the Northern Deng"* or *"Clearly Inspect the Ghostly Encampment"*—adding the word *"seal"* and arranging them in three lines—take eight characters from the scriptures as a single seal. If this logic were followed, the *Celestial Script Salvation of Humanity Scripture* could yield a seal for every character from beginning to end, an innumerable multitude.

There are also those who style themselves the *Altar of Mystic Communication with the Numinous* or the *Numinous Treasure Mystic Altar*, not only usurping celestial protocol but also violating the statutes of the yang principle. The Three Mao Mountains of Jinling are the ancestral altar of the Great Cavern tradition; Hefu Mountain by the Linjiang River is the ancestral altar of the Numinous Treasure tradition; and Longhu Mountain in Xinzhou is the ancestral altar of the Orthodox Unity tradition. These are the sacred sites where the Three Caverns’ sagely masters transmitted the true teachings and presided over the canon, revered by successive dynasties. If commoners conduct fasting rites, they may temporarily erect an altar, but once the ritual is complete, it is dismantled. How could one arbitrarily establish a name for a private dwelling?

Those who attain the subtleties of *Mystic Communication* could discern the great fortunes and calamities of the world, the auspices and disasters of the celestial divisions, and the cycles of destiny’s rise and fall. Yet such knowledge is forbidden by secular law. Without sufficient merit and cultivation, one must not indulge in such reckless presumption.

There are also the *Bureau of the Nine Spirits’ Flying Petitions* and the *Seal of the Nine Spirits’ Flying Petitions*. The term *"flying petitions"* refers to the act of pacing the stars to invoke the Nine Spirits—it is merely the name of a ritual step in memorializing. There is no such bureau in heaven, nor such a seal in the world. From the Orthodox Unity to the Cavern Mystery traditions, all may submit memorials according to their proper offices. The Orthodox Unity ritualists use the *Nine Elders of the Immortal Capital Seal*, while the Cavern Mystery ritualists use the *General Memorial Seal*. There are no alternative doctrines; why, then, would one need to fabricate an additional title or craft a special seal to submit a memorial?

In secular terms, officials from the *shoucuo* rank upward may submit memorials to the court, merely inscribing their current office as their title. They do not establish a separate rank for memorial submissions beyond their proper office. According to ancient texts and master transmissions, one need only append a single title: for all memorials, dispatches, talismans, and documents, the *Seal of the Numinous Treasure Great Dharma Bureau* is used. For memorial submissions, only the *General Memorial Seal* is employed. In urgent petitions, the *Yellow Spirit Transcendent Memorial Seal* is used. For other matters, such as summoning souls, the *Divine Tiger Seal* is employed.

In all rituals—whether setting up offerings, conducting fasts, praying for rain or sunshine, summoning spirits, capturing ghosts, healing illnesses, investigating malevolent influences, delivering the deceased, or saving the living—the twenty-seven grades of fasts and forty-two types of offerings, along with all worldly practices within the Numinous Treasure’s purview, are encompassed by the use of these four seals alone. There is nothing they cannot accomplish.

When performing the *Heart of Heaven* rites and conducting the *Northern Dipper Offering*, one follows the proper method of the tradition: the *Exorcism Bureau Seal* is used for those who have advanced to the Cavern Mystery rank. For the *Northern Dipper Offering* in the Cavern Mystery tradition, the *Seal of the Numinous Treasure Great Dharma Bureau* suffices. The principle is exhaustive. When merit is perfected and the Cavern Vision is fully realized, when one’s conduct is exalted and spirits are commanded to serve, there is no need to proliferate seals further.

Beyond the Numinous Treasure, those who practice other methods follow their respective regulations and use their corresponding seals.

The submission of talismanic memorials and official documents may likewise employ only the seals of the Numinous Treasure’s proper offices.

For the Supreme Clarity Cavern Realms possess no system of memorials or ritual forms, while the Numinous Treasure stands as the supreme rank of the Middle Vehicle. All methods below the Orthodox Unity tradition may not transcend the Numinous Treasure. Thus, though various miscellaneous seals have circulated for so long that they cannot be abruptly abolished, they are now preserved together. Scholars devoted to antiquity and refinement shall discern for themselves.

**Ritual for Consecrating Seals**
The Master declares: The seal-charters are the numinous writ of the Three Heavens, the talismanic covenants of the exalted perfected. When activated, Jade Maidens attend as guards; when employed, spirit-officials enforce their authority. Matters proceed according to the seal’s function—no transgression is permitted.

For the ritual of seal consecration, prepare twelve portions each of jujube decoction and pure tea, twelve bright lamps, and twelve sets of spirit-money and paper horses. Arrange these before the Gate of Heaven. At the hour when the stellar lodges shine clearly, the Dharma Master dons ritual vestments and cap, purifies the mind, and offers incense. Joining the middle fingers of both hands, he gathers the qi of the ten directions and blows it upon himself, transforming into the Numinous Treasure Heavenly Worthy. Upon his head rests the Seven Mornings Jade Canopy Crown of Interlocking Harmony; his body is clad in a robe of azure feathers and flying clouds, crimson slippers, and a scarlet skirt. At his waist hangs the Numinous Treasure Sword of the Three Realms; upon his back rests the Five-Colored Circular Symbol. Standing in the *ding* position and facing south, he paces the Eight Trigrams in homage to Heaven, then turns to face the Gate of Heaven. Bowing thrice, he rises and silently memorializes the Supreme Emperor, stating the number of seals to be transmitted and the chosen day for the ritual consecration.

He invokes the Three Worthies to deign to gaze upon him, beseeching them to bestow the Primordial Three Qi of the Mysterious Origin and infuse them into the seals. He commands twenty-four Golden Lads and Jade Maidens to serve as attendants, enabling him to employ the seals with numinous efficacy. Whatever responses manifest, the sagely beings of the ten directions shall bear witness.

Upon completing the memorial, he bows thrice again, draws in the three qi of the Gate of Heaven, and blows them into the seals. Kneeling upright, he takes each seal in turn, traces the *Great Execution Talisman* with both hands, and raises it to his forehead to empower it.

**Empowerment Incantation for the Seal**
The Elixir of Enspirited Cinnabar shines,
The numinous plain commands the Mysterious Heaven.
The majestic form of Mysterious Heaven abides,
Its radiant yin aspect embracing the Great Transformation.
The Pivot of the Square Mysterious responds to the vast,
The settled ministers endure in blessed flourishing.

After reciting the incantation, he draws in three breaths of qi, blows them forth, flicks the Jade Clarity Mudra, and recites the *Numinous Writ* once more before placing the seals in their casket.

**Method for Employing the Seal**
With the left hand forming the *zi* mudra, recite the incantation:

**Oṃ vāru-vara-maṇḍa-yin-di-seṭa-nā u-hū-xī-dī shè.**

**Method for Activating the Seal**
With the left hand forming the *wu* mudra, recite the incantation:
Oṃ maśu-mī-dī xū-ní ā-duō-yē nà wū-yín dì luó.

**Incantation for Imprinting the Seal**
With the left hand forming the *zhong-zhong* mudra, recite the incantation:
Oṃ bō-nà hěn-nà wū lú mó sà-hā.

**Incantation for the Inkstone**
With the left hand pinching the upper joint of the middle finger, recite the incantation:
Oṃ miǎo-mǎng wū shuǎng jù zhī pí chá shè.

**Incantation for the Water**
With the left hand forming the *zi* mudra and the right holding the water, recite the incantation:
Oṃ yù-dān bó-hè hán jīng tuó-luó jǐng xuán shè.

**Incantation for the Paper**
With the left middle finger in the *zhong* mudra and the right holding the paper, recite the incantation:
Oṃ pú-yù tán-nà mó luó ā nà shè.

**Incantation for the Cinnabar**
With the left hand forming the *wu* mudra and the right holding the cinnabar, recite the incantation:
Oṃ tuó luó ā nà yuán fàn pú tái shè.

**Incantation for the Ink**
With the left hand forming the *zi* mudra and the right grinding nine revolutions, recite the incantation:
Oṃ xíng xuán tuó hé yōu lǜ pàn shè.

**Incantation for the Brush**
With the left hand forming the *yin* mudra and the right holding the brush, aligning it with the mouth, recite the incantation:
Oṃ yù zhú luó méng mó luó ā yì xū fù shè.

**Ritual for Offering to Cinnabar, Ink, Brush, and Inkstone**
The method states: On a day governed by the Six Ding or Six Jia spirits, prepare twelve brushes, twelve sticks of ink, twelve ounces of cinnabar (or less if poor), and two inkstones. On a *jiǎzǐ* day, face the Celestial Gate and arrange them upon the table. Offer twelve cups of jujube broth and one incense burner, ensuring no one disturbs the ritual.

The officiant forms the *zi* mudra with the left hand and the *wu* mudra with the right, crossing them at the mouth.

**Prayer:**
Your servant now, in accordance with the prescribed form, has prepared brushes, ink, cinnabar, and inkstones, arranging them beneath the Celestial Gate. Reverently, I invoke the numinous officials of the *Lingbao* scriptural departments, the immortals of the celestial bureaus, the Golden Lads and Jade Maidens, the generals, officers, and soldiers—may each infuse these implements with their transforming true *qi*, so that when I employ them, they respond at will with divine efficacy.

**Incantation for Offering to the Brush**
Oṃ ā nà fǎ yán mó yí ā yǎng mì luó pú tí pó lóu sà luó fàn nà zǒng jiān guǐ shén shè.

After reciting the incantation, flick the mudra, draw in twelve breaths from the Celestial Gate, and blow them into the brush. Inscribe the talisman within the brush shaft, reciting:
The divine brush, numinous and bright,
Moves by the Mandate of the Supreme.
The Upper Realm receives its command,
All spirits heed with reverence.
Inscribed talismans and registers,
Penetrate the profound and obscure.
Within the Mysterious, the Great Sovereign,
The Lofty Perfected of the Supreme.
Govern the Five *Qi*,
Merge with the hundred spirits.
Swiftly, swiftly, as the *Lingbao* Great Law commands!

**Talisman for Activating the Brush**
**Talisman for Offering to the Generals**

**Incantation for Inscribing Talismans**
Oṃ yè gé tú qú hē lè tán jù pó yí zhī dì sà zhà.

For this method, press the middle of the middle finger, inscribe ten talismans, write them on red paper, and distribute them to the ten directions. For each talisman, burn yellow paper money while reciting:
A thousand harmonies, ten thousand unions,
Merge with the hundred spirits.
Divine Lords receive the Mandate,
Overseeing all numinous beings.
All demons bow their heads,
All spirits submit in reverence.
Guard the true and secure destiny,
To deliver the multitudes.
In life and death, they rely upon it,
Its blessings are boundless.
Merits and transgressions are never lost,
Protect and exalt your being.
Swiftly, swiftly, as the *Lingbao* Law commands!

**The Twenty-Seventh Scroll of the Supreme Purity Lingbao Great Law Concludes**

**The Twenty-Eighth Scroll of the Supreme Purity Lingbao Great Law**
Transmitted by Dongwei Gaoshi, Kaiguang Jiuku Zhenren Ning Quanzhen, to the Supreme Purity Three Caverns Disciple, Lingbao Lineage Master Wang Qizhen

**Chapter on Transmission Rituals and Standards**
The Master said: The *Lingbao* Great Law is the supreme Dao of the Three Caverns and Three Ranks, the numinous chapters of ten thousand, a hundred, and a thousand scrolls. Those who receive it are not distinguished by immortality or mortality, but rather by having scriptures to serve as their teacher. Those who transmit it do not select by nobility or baseness, but rather by having seekers to serve as their disciples.

According to the *Xuan Du Ding Lu*, the transmission of the forty thousand decrees is not based on the rank of the lower terrestrial realm, but rather on the time limits of the Three Heavens. This is to prevent its leakage to unworthy persons. If one possesses the talent of an immortal, why should it be limited to the transmission of forty thousand decrees at a time?

The statutes of the Divine Continent forbid the release of its texts for four hundred years, though it permits a perfected person to transmit them to one person every forty years. Within four hundred years, no more than seven persons may receive them. However, one must be cautious, for if later learners who transmit and practice it are numerous, they may betray the Dao, forsake their teachers, violate their vows, fail to comprehend the profound principles, mock and misuse the Daoist methods, carelessly leak secrets, and offend against the Mysterious Mandate. Not only will they ruin the sacred teachings, but they will also betray their teachers and masters. Their ranks will be demoted, and they will ultimately find it difficult to return to the Upper Palaces. Moreover, those without the proper bone constitution will implicate their immortal ancestors—this cannot be ignored.

There are also reckless and arrogant masters who happen upon these texts. Outwardly, they display lofty virtue and purity, but inwardly, they covet wealth and goods. Without discerning the worthy and wise, they indiscriminately teach the unworthy, thereby confusing the sacred teachings. This causes the Three Officials to wield their brushes and the Four Departments to record transgressions, leading to a dissonance between the Dao’s wonders and the numinous mysteries, rendering them as empty as the void.

Yet the Upper Mysterious Ones, who cherish life and abhor killing, universally deliver the submerged and lost. They extend the boundless decree of delivering all beings and guide later learners. Thus, they have established separate transmission standards to ensure harmony and yang light prevail, preventing the rise of yin and killing. Disciples should adhere to these, assist in propagating the Mysterious Transformation, so that all under heaven embrace virtue and together attain the fruit of the Great Luo.

The Perfected of the Supreme Ultimate said: Since receiving the decree of old, I have fully experienced transformations, whether in wealth or poverty, nobility or lowliness, without exception. In the transmission between teacher and disciple, every word and phrase must be free of true or false distinctions. If one takes the false as true, one naturally obtains a true response. If one takes the true as false, the true is lost of itself, and the distinction between true and false arises. Thus it is said: The myriad methods arise from the distinction between true and false; the cinnabar palace is disturbed by qi, and the ten thousand decrees become obscure. If one’s heart is devoted to the true and dismisses the false, one immediately attains the wondrous fruit of true response.

The Perfected of Brahma-void said: At the beginning of transmission, the principles of pledging the heart and swearing the covenant are established because learners of the Dao are shallow and superficial, lacking pure and sincere resolve. Thus, there are standards for pledging with gold and treasures, valuing the Dao over wealth. Yet some lose the true transmission due to excessive attachment to wealth, while others, obsessed with profit, measure it in ounces and grains, thereby losing the proper recipient. Those who inherit the Dharma in this manner are not genuine, their original hearts eroded. Though divine retribution has not yet arrived, how can they escape the punishment of spirits and gods?

The Master said: In the standards of transmission, one must carefully select the recipient. Their inner spirit must be firm, their virtue and dignity solemn, their words and deeds trustworthy, and they must be compassionate, loyal, and filial. They must be frugal, upright in conduct, their hearts sincere and upright, and their aspirations long for the subtle and formless. Only such a person is fit to practice the supreme methods and deliver the living and the dead.

If one harbors secret schemes to harm others, their words and deeds are flawed, loyalty and filial piety are absent, their hearts and conduct are wicked and deceitful, they are cunning and fraudulent, lacking inner virtue and outer dignity—then they are persons of shallow blessings and deep wickedness. Or if they come from families of executioners, soldiers, or those who inflict punishment and death in the three paths, how can they comprehend the gods and spirits of heaven and earth? One must discern the wise from the foolish, distinguish the constitution of immortals, and only then may they receive the words, take the oath, follow the time limits of the Mysterious Statutes, prepare the words of the heart’s chapter, and obtain the oral command of the Great Marshal—who is none other than the Celestial Worthy of Primordial Beginning. Next, seek the endorsement of the lineage master, who shares the altar with the master of transmission, and report to the Three Heavens’ ministers, submitting to the Three Officials’ offices to receive a favorable response. Only then, choose an auspicious day and transmit according to the statutes, swearing an oath to heaven.

It is also said: Generally, a master who receives and upholds the Dharma may transmit it to five persons after practicing for half a cycle (six years). After a full cycle (twelve years), they may transmit it tenfold compared to other methods—this must be strictly observed.

**Pledging the Heart and Swearing to Heaven**
The Scripture says: The noble person treasures gold and treasures, pledging their heart and swearing to heaven before transmission. It also says: If a perfected person pledges their heart, they must follow the old standards and report the oath to the Ten Heavens before transmission. This is how one pledges the heart and honors the Dao.

The standards for reporting the oath are as follows: If feudal lords, dukes, or ministers wish to save the world, aid the endangered, and secure the nation’s destiny by receiving this great Dharma, they should offer one hundred twenty taels of fine gold, thirty-six bolts each of five-colored silks and gauzes, twelve taels each of cinnabar and green silk, one hundred twenty *dan* of rice as a pledge, one hundred twenty strings of cash, and thirty-six catties of incense for the oath.

If scholars or commoners wish to deliver the living and the dead, ascend their immortal ancestors, they should offer thirty-six taels of fine gold, ten bolts each of five-colored silks and gauzes, nine taels each of cinnabar and green silk, twelve *dan* of rice as a pledge, twelve strings of cash, and six catties of incense for the oath.

If one retreats to the mountains and forests, practices austerities in secluded valleys, and cultivates the Dao, they should offer nine taels of fine gold, one bolt of purple silk, one tael each of green silk and cinnabar, and one catty of incense for the oath. One hundred sheets of paper may substitute for silk and cloth, and one set each of five-direction brushes and ink may substitute for cash and rice.

Should those of insufficient means to practice the Dao still offer two-thirds of these requirements, yet nothing may be omitted. For those of meager circumstances dwelling in cold seclusion, they may shear their hair in place of gold, petitioning the Thirty-Two Heavenly Emperors of the Celestial Courts to swear alliance with the Ten Heavens. Alternatively, offer five-colored cloth measuring three feet and six inches as a token of sincerity. Or, pierce the flesh to draw blood in substitution, presenting it to the Five Emperors as a pledge of devotion, thereby bestowing it upon the Jade Lads and Jade Maidens. Green silk may serve in place of shorn hair, and cinnabar in place of drawn blood.

Though clear pledges and trustworthy offerings now exist, few indeed are those who would shear their hair or pierce their flesh. Yet the essence of sincerity lies in severing a portion of one’s own flesh, cutting the sacred treasures of the Nine Heavens, heedless of shame or pain, to forge bonds of ten thousand karmic blessings, thereby revealing the purity of one’s heart. Swear never to transmit this recklessly or with negligence. Truly, such a one is the rightful recipient—what need has he for worldly wealth?

For this method is concealed within the Upper Heavens, its prohibitions most severe. Even celestial beings, when journeying to the Mystic Capital’s Upper Palace to receive transmission, must still offer gold and treasures—thus may it not be lightly divulged. If a Dao-practitioner seeks to transmit the dharma, the master must memorialize the Celestial Court in full detail, following the prescribed rites for transmission. All requisite items for transmission must not be concealed out of selfishness.

Should a disciple outwardly惜财货而轻道, inwardly惜肤而耻痛, and thus fail to sincerely pledge, the Dao will not take root, and the divine immortals will not attend the scriptures. After transmission, both master and disciple will be assailed by a hundred demons, incurring profound misfortune, burdening their ancestors, and betraying the Mystic. Beware this most earnestly.

If one adheres to the regulations, all heavens will rejoice, the myriad demons will be bound, and the host of spirits will pay homage. When the altar is opened and the transmission conferred, the assembled perfected ones will oversee the rite, bestowing it upon the recipient. The Dao and its methods will flourish, the hundred demons will retreat into silence, and the natural ebb and flow of separation and union will prevail. Summon the sages, gather the perfected, deliver the living, ferry the dead, accumulate merit, and amass virtue—success will be achieved in no time.

The recipient of this dharma must be loyal and filial to sovereign, master, parents, and teachers; compassionate toward the suffering souls of the netherworld; devoted in heart to the Three Treasures; pure and steadfast in self-cultivation; containing brilliance in silent recognition; practicing hidden virtues in secret; maintaining single-minded focus from beginning to end; and never forgetting the subtle words of the master. Be sincere, earnest, and unwavering in observance.

In official rank or salary, one may serve the sovereign and support kin; dwelling in mountains and forests, one need not shun refining body and spirit; delighting in rivers and lakes, one may roam freely without remorse; tending fields, one may not neglect plowing, planting, and harvest; concealed among merchants and traders, one may not hinder commerce and enterprise; hidden among physicians, diviners, artisans, and craftsmen, one may not suppress skill and mastery in one’s craft. Concealed in obscurity, one will surely succeed; flaunting brilliance, one will surely fall.

If one disdains superiors and neglects inferiors, flatters and follows power, schemes with cunning, is frivolous and easily wearied, debates trivialities, is arrogant toward all, pursues ostentation and profit, spreads idle praise, indulges in lust, drunkenness, greed, and anger, or fails to establish resolve and conduct—such a one is unfit. If one adheres to the teachings and precepts, one may securely ascend, and the ranks of immortality may be attained.

This is the teaching of my school, not to be shown to the uninitiated. Strive to uphold it with care, and comprehend it clearly in full.

The Master said: For all who bow in reverence with the *Heart Chapter*, having already received the mandate of the Supreme Mystery, permission to transmit the precepts and confer ordination is granted. Again, employ the *Heart Chapter* to communicate below within the oratory, whether upon lofty mountains. The *Revealed Chapter* is divided into the *Ten Celestial Treasure Contracts*, the *Joint Office Contracts*, and the *Mystic Capital Oath Contracts*. Proclaim the covenant to the Ten Heavens, offering *Mystic Spring Lingzhi*, rare blossoms, precious fruits, and fragrant incense. Perform thirty-two prostrations to the Master as a token of gratitude for the endorsement, to assume the appointed office. All these are witnessed by the hundred spirits, who attend the Jade Steps of the divine court with luminous clarity. Only then may one enter the purport of the *Seven Scriptures*, and thereafter offer thanksgiving rites to all Masters.

If the *Heart Chapter* has been transmitted and the mandate of the Mystery permits ordination, establish the covenant and oath, complete the rites of reverence and division of the contract with the Master, and all may be permitted to become Masters of the Mystery within the Heavens, entering the Dao of the *Seven Scriptures*. Erect an altar for self-ordination, without necessarily relying on an ordaining Master to preside. Yet one must still engage a Master of the Scriptures in the world to reach the Master of the Mystery. There are no ordinations without the Master of the Scriptures, just as there are no accomplishments without the Master of the Mystery. The Master of the Scriptures and the Master of the Mystery are not distinct; should there be the slightest deviation in devotion, the two bureaus will memorialize and impeach, demoting the offender and deducting their allotted years.

The remainder follows the *Mystic Statutes and Immortal Registers*. Upon completion of the ordination, take nine inches of yellow silk, inscribe upon it the *Flowing Gold Refined Body Longevity Spirit Talisman* in cinnabar, and on the reverse, the *Nine Precepts*. Enclose it in a crimson pouch and suspend it before the heart. Uphold the *Nine Perfected Great Precepts*, receive and practice the *Ten Precepts of the Dharma Office*, the *Twelve Practices of Heavenly Beings*, and recite the *Divine Book Hymn Chapters* ten thousand times. Only then may one enter the *Seven Scriptures*, and afterward hold the *Eight Wefts*, inevitably attaining the rank of Perfected. Even if merits are incomplete and one enters the underworld, one may temporarily escape to the Great Yin, achieve liberation through *corpse-transcendence*, and ascend to the Immortal Palaces.

**Petition for Transmission of the Great Dao**

Having purified body and mind through fasting and ablutions, and bearing offerings of incense and faith, I personally approach the altar of my Preceptor [Name], Master of Transmission, to humbly petition for the conferral of the **Great Rites of Supreme Clarity and Numinous Treasure (Shangqing Lingbao)**, including its scriptures, esoteric oral instructions, talismanic diagrams, and seals—all as one transmission.

I vow to uphold and practice these rites, universally aiding the living and the dead, refining body and spirit, safeguarding family and state, promoting benefit and eradicating harm, establishing virtue and merit. I dare not resent the Dao or fault my master, nor slacken in diligence from beginning to end. Should I leak secret texts or recklessly reveal them to the unworthy, may calamity flow upon my person, misfortune extend to my seven generations, and may I, upon the wind’s touch or blade’s edge, be examined and forever forfeit my place among humanity.

This petition is respectfully submitted and prostrated before the altar of my Preceptor, the **Three Caverns’ Patriarch and Perfected [Name]**.

I humbly implore the merciful favor of my Master to deign approval, and to specially memorialize the **Celestial Court (Tian Ting)**, that transmission may proceed in accordance with the ordained statutes. I await the **Dharma Decree** in reverence.

Let it be known that the disciple [Name] has received the **Dharma** office and seal script, that all may be made aware.

Thus shall [Name] be pardoned for past transgressions, his sins expunged from the ledgers, his name inscribed in the Jade Register, and his person enrolled in the **Mysterious Capital**. Whether for state or for the people, whether in prayers for averting misfortune or in supplications, whether in delivering the living or ferrying the dead, whether in conducting fasts to establish merit, or in issuing talismans and decrees—wherever his covenants and pledges extend, may there be no obstruction, and may all swiftly come to fruition.

I further beseech the descent of the **Primordial Three Qi of the Mysterious Origin**, the wondrous radiance of the **Numinous Treasure**, to flow into the **Hun Yuan** spirit-chamber of [Name], that in his contemplation and practice, in his breath and cultivation, the profound talismans and mysterious workings may be mastered, and the **True Spirits** fully communicated. Thus shall there be none he cannot deliver, and nothing he cannot accomplish.

When the **jiao** offering reaches its appointed time, I shall reverently await the grace of the **Enlightened Light** to descend upon the altar, bearing witness to the rites performed.

This servant, of foolish and impure substance, has recklessly occupied a place among the immortal ranks, presuming upon the **August Majesty**—my crimes merit ten thousand punishments. Respectfully I present this memorial and prostrate myself in await of the **Decree of Command**.

By the Illuminating and Compassionate Perfected of Profound Mystery, the High Master Ning Quanzhen, the Radiant Light Savior from Suffering, transmitted to Wang Qizhen, Disciple of the Three Caverns of Highest Clarity and Successor of the Lingbao Teaching:

**Memorial to the Officials and Generals of the Lingbao Dharma Departments, Lingbao Grand Dharma Bureau**

In accordance with the petition submitted by the disciple [Surname] [Given Name], jointly memorializing the Celestial Court to request the transmission of precepts and ordination, and having already presented a memorial to the Imperial Court and notified the Three Realms through official documents to the appropriate Perfected Bureaus, this memorial now separately lists the disciple’s received Daoist office and seal-script in an attached register, appended herewith for due transmission.

**Hereby memorialized to:**
The Myriad-Willed Great General of the Lingbao Grand Dharma’s Ten Thousand Bureaus; the Radiant Myriad Deities of the Heavens; Jade Maidens and Jade Lads; Numinous Officials, Generals, and Tiger Spirits; the Two Great Saints of the Northern Dipper’s Mystic Model; the Seven Perfected Jade Maidens; the Messengers of the Three Departments; the Officers and Soldiers of the Soul-Snatching and Spirit-Seizing Bureau; the Left and Right Great Generals of the Southern Prosperity Refinement Bureau’s Cinnabar Heaven; the Officials and Clerks of the Water and Fire Bureaus’ Refinement Offices; the Relevant Officials of the Yellow Register Bureau’s Examination and Verification Departments; the Officers, Generals, and Soldiers of the Petition-Transmitting and Spirit-Mobilizing Daoist Bureaus; the Numinous Officials and Immortal Stewards of the Celestial Physicians’ Court; the Jade Lads and Jade Maidens, Messengers, Officers, Soldiers, and Relevant Generals and Aides of all Lingbao Departments, Bureaus, and Courts:

**Respectfully beseeched to:**
Receive the Mandate of Highest Heaven, secretly divide and manifest your true forms, and on the appointed day descend as one to the [Name] Oratory and Retreat. There, assume your respective offices, establish your ranks, and attend to your duties.

Henceforth, whenever the disciple undertakes rites for state and populace—praying for clear skies or rain, aiding the afflicted, delivering the suffering of the netherworld, transcending ancestral spirits, refining qi and cultivating form, achieving inner vision and morning audience with the Dao, presenting memorials and tributes, performing fasts and practicing the Way, or cultivating virtue and establishing merit—may you all attend in advance and follow thereafter, assist to the left and support to the right, respond instantly whether seated or standing, and manifest in form when envisioned in mind. Let the sacred and the mortal interact, the divine and the vital harmonize in secret accord, ensuring that commands are executed without fail and that no movement goes unanswered. Forever aid the teachings of the Mysterious Origin, jointly advancing the benevolence of salvation. Swear an oath as unyielding as metal and stone, ever steadfast as limbs to the body. Accumulate merit in delivering the living and transcending the dead, fulfill the vows of studying the Dao and cultivating the Perfected, propagate the great transformation, and proclaim the true wind. Strive diligently in your duties, and should your efforts ever falter, may your achievements be renewed with praise.

Furthermore, beseeched to acknowledge and uphold the disciple’s received Daoist office and seal-script, along with all relevant talismans, petitions, and covenants. Wherever these may arrive, ensure they are duly observed without refusal or hindrance, thereby manifesting great merit in service. Memorialized for compliance; let none dare to neglect or defy.

**Respectfully memorialized.**

**Lingbao Ordination Vows and Precepts**
*Issued by the Altar of Mysterious Transmission of the Great Ritual of the Numinous Treasure to the dharma-successor disciple [Name] for reception and observance.*

In strict adherence to the *Great Ritual*, the following vows and precepts are hereby conferred:

**Ten Vows of the Numinous Treasure:**
1. To aspire to long life with joy.
2. To depart from death and enter life.
3. To refine qi and unite with form.
4. To deliver all sentient beings.
5. To wish for universal peace under Heaven.
6. To awaken all beings to the Dao.
7. To ensure the ascension of ancestral spirits.
8. To forever depart from the offices of ghosts.
9. To perfect both form and spirit.
10. To unite with the Dao in truth.

**Five Precepts of the Numinous Treasure:**
1. To refrain from killing and harm, ever practicing forbearance.
2. To eschew jealousy and arrogance, ever preserving others’ achievements.
3. To abstain from licentiousness and theft, ever acting with integrity.
4. To avoid defilement in food and drink, ever cultivating shame and modesty.
5. To sever all frivolous and extravagant poetry, ever practicing kindness and frugality.

**Ten Oaths of the Numinous Treasure:**
1. Never to become greatly intoxicated or give rise to anger.
2. Never to suffer hunger or surfeit, nor exhaust the body with toil.
3. Never to harbor grand ambitions or distant desires.
4. Never to recklessly associate with unworthy persons.
5. Never to take wealth that is not rightfully obtained.
6. Never to resent the Dao or blame one’s master.
7. Never to recklessly recite or misuse sacred texts.
8. Never to recklessly harm spirits or gods.

**Ten Virtues of the Numinous Treasure:**
1. To pity the aged and succor the orphaned.
2. To enter the temples of the gods.

8. Never to recklessly disclose secret scriptures.
9. Never to recklessly disclose secret scriptures.

**Ten Virtues of the Numinous Treasure (continued):**
2. To pity the poor and aid the widowed.
3. To deliver and relieve the suffering of the departed.
4. To distribute elixirs and medicines.
5. To revere and honor all beings.
6. To diligently perform talismanic water rituals.
7. To constantly recite scriptures and incantations.
8. To widely create scriptures and images.
9. To diligently uphold fasting and precepts.
10. To release and prolong life.

This document is hereby conferred upon the dharma-successor disciple [Name], who shall uphold these oaths and precepts without fail, maintaining unwavering resolve in body and mind. Thus shall they be delivered from the Three Wretched Realms, spared from the Six Paths of Rebirth, guarded by all heavens, and revered by the myriad sages. It is fitting to diligently practice fasting, uphold the precepts, cultivate an impartial and upright mind, keep intentions clear, single-mindedly turn toward the Dao, focus thought without duality, and maintain inner and outer purity and emptiness, ever in accord with the natural. The mirror of the Dao responds to your heart—conduct yourself with precept and practice. Be a model for the Three Realms, an exemplar before ghosts and spirits, attaining communion with the true and penetration of the numinous, where body and spirit are both perfected. The Dao does not fail those who do not fail it; it is imperative to reverently comply, diligently practice, and sincerely receive, thereby propagating the profound wind of the Dao. Hence this document.

Dated: [Year] [Month] [Day]

Listed guarantors and supervising preceptors hold the same titles as before.

**Ring Formula**
The ring may be made of one tael and two mace of silver, inscribed with talismanic characters in cinnabar, with a central aperture. Two rings are used, bound together with blue silk, then severed with a knife at the altar. Master and disciple each retain one ring, storing them in a yellow silk pouch alongside the matching contract.

**Thought-Mystery Contract Formula**
In the [Year] of the Great Year [Celestial Stem-Branch], on the [Day] of the [Month] of [Dynasty], in the [State] of [Location], [Full Name], of [Place of Origin], this day respectfully pledges a golden treasure of sincerity. Following the standards of the Mystic Capital, they ally with the Ten Heavens, bowing in reverence.

Having received the transmission of the Shangqing Numinous Treasure scriptures, methods, memorials, and esoteric texts, they shall practice the Dao according to ritual, dispelling all inauspiciousness and universally delivering the boundless. On the day of receiving the Dao, their name is recorded in the Southern Palace; ten thousand spirits attend them. Their body transcends the Three Realms, their rank ascends to that of an immortal elder. The Demon Kings vouch for them, and the host of perfected beings supervises their transmission. The preceptor, in humble compliance with the great Dharma, invokes the divine perfected, delivering heaven and humanity. They dare not conceal or improperly transmit this teaching, swearing an oath by the Heaven within Heaven.

After receiving the Dharma, the disciple must not recklessly disclose it to the unworthy. Should they violate this sworn covenant, their body shall dwell in the demonic palace, their lifespan shortened, their years diminished. For ten thousand kalpas, they shall undergo trial, forever bound to the wheel of rebirth, with calamity extending to their seven generations.

Herein is established the covenant document as a surety.

The dharma-successor disciple [Name], aged [Age] in this life, born in the year [Year], month [Month], day [Day], hour [Hour], belongs to [Sacred Peak] and is summoned by the [Celestial Qi] Lord of [Heaven].

Reverently invoking:
The Celestial Venerable of Primordial Beginning to deliver,

On this day of joyous deliverance, [Name] passes through the gates of the myriad heavens, beseeching the eradication of the Three Ones’ evil, the severing of earthly roots, the transcendence of the Five Portals, and the inscription of their name in the Great Mystery. The Demon King of the First Heaven supervises their elevation, unbound by the gates of heaven.

The Eastern Dipper governs lifespan,

the myriad spirits cannot transgress.

This covenant is entrusted to disciple [Name] to safeguard as a treasure of the body, enabling flight through the heavens below, distant acclamation by the Thearchs, homage from the myriad spirits, attendance by the Three Realms, submission of demonic hordes, self-annihilation of ghostly essences, prostration of the myriad numina, the summoning of immortal hosts, profound wisdom and luminous clarity, and the vast measure of the Mysterious Mystery.

Swiftly, swiftly, in accordance with the statutes of the Great Dharma of the Numinous Treasure’s covenant transmission!

**Inscription:**
The Primordial Azure’s mystery transforms the myriad into form.
The mother’s blood, the father’s essence—
blood as lead, mercury as essence,
blood as qi, mercury as spirit.
Lead is yang, mercury is yin.
Lead and mercury become the gate of yin and yang,
the root of creation as sun and moon.
Mercury governs emotion, lead governs nature.
When spirit and nature are still, the earth abides eternally without turning;
when spirit is wild, lead descends and mercury departs from its root.
When nature is chaotic, mercury flees and lead loses its authenticity.
The myriad demons transform and arise in the Three Palaces.
When nature is restless and spirit scatters,
the Numinous Treasure is lost—how can one seek the true?
How may the myriad attain ascension?
Deeply investigate lead and mercury, discerning purity from turbidity,
proceeding step by step.
Master its diagram—this is the esoteric essence of cultivation.
Clarify its text—this is the gateway of the Great Dao.
Should one recklessly pair myriad unsuitable elements,
hoping for the Numinous Treasure elixir’s completion,
transformation of the embryo and spirit, and ascension in broad daylight,
even trial would prove difficult.
Should one recklessly disclose this to the unworthy,
the wind-knife shall immediately examine them,
and for ten thousand kalpas, there shall be no absolution.

This covenant is inscribed on catalpa wood, one foot and two inches in length, with an azure background and vermilion script for talismans and characters, stored in a yellow bag.

**The Master states:** The *Thought-Concealing Stabilizing Will Talisman* is the essential purport of the Great Dao, the supreme secret of the Numinous Treasure. Those who comprehend it attain longevity; those who cultivate it become immortals. Now, its outline is presented—disciples should examine it in detail.

**Proclamation of the Three Heavens Gate**

Of old, when chaos first divided, the Primordial Beginning unfolded its chart; the true writ shone resplendent in the Divine Empyrean, and jade characters spread forth across the Azure Vault. Divine spirits descended in substance, and precious qi gathered in form, embracing primordial qi within the Great Void, revolving yin and yang through cold and heat. They govern the Three Realms, restrain the myriad demons, their sacred tablets and jade tablets, their jasper cases and alchemical slips—scriptures esteemed as supreme, methods unrivaled in the Central Palace. They are the origin of all things, the ancestor of the mysterious mechanism, most revered among the heavens.

Through diligent toil may one hear of them; discerning the worthy from the foolish, we now follow the ancient statutes. We pledge before the Ten Heavens to present our oath, and transmit the precious gold and precious treasures in succession. To recklessly disclose secret texts brings calamity upon nine generations.

Today, on this day, so-and-so respectfully offers nine taels of superior gold, one bolt of purple damask, one tael of green silk, one catty of oath-incense, and steps forward to the altar. Bowing, I pray for myself, born in such-and-such a year, such-and-such a life-destiny, on such-and-such a month, day, and hour. Reflecting deeply, I, so-and-so, am of pure heart and steadfast intent, guarding the Dao with unwavering sincerity. In accordance with the Mysterious Statutes of the Most High, I now pledge and transmit the covenant.

Having received auspicious retribution, I am fittingly bestowed with immortal rank and commendation. I hereby recommend:

**Sponsoring Master:** The Ten Directions’ Most Perfected Flying Heavenly Divine Kings, Great Sages of Everlasting Life, Boundless Great Spirits.
**Supervising Master:** The Thirty-Two Heavenly Lords, Perfected of Wondrous Conduct.
**Transmitting Master:** The Ten Directions’ Numinous Treasure Heavenly Venerables, Void Sovereign Dao Lords.
**Scripture Master:** The Nine Heavens’ Lofty and Illustrious Great Envoys, Perfected Lords of Divine Merit and Wondrous Aid.
**Register Master:** The Three Heavens’ Great Dharma Masters, Perfected of Orthodox Unity and Serene Response.
**Transmitting Master:** The Great Dharma Master of the Mysterious Center, Void Sovereign Serene Elder Heavenly Venerable.

The Lord of the Eastern Dipper who Records Destiny grants transmission.
The Lord of the Southern Dipper who Bestows Life grants transmission.
The Lord of the Western Dipper who Records Names grants transmission.
The Lord of the Northern Dipper who Seals Death grants transmission.
The Lord of the Central Dipper, Great Luminary, grants transmission.

Respectfully following...
