**Chapter on Altar Canopies**
The Master said: To worship Heaven and Earth and commune with the perfected immortals, one must establish an altar to express utmost reverence. The altar formats for the Three Caverns’ retreat rituals vary in rank and differ in specifications, each detailed in their respective methods. Here, we focus solely on the *Yellow Register* retreat altar, thus not addressing others. The format is as follows.

**Format of the Lingbao Ascension and Salvation Mysterious Altar:**
According to the *Lower Prime Yellow Register Tablets* and the *Numinous Immortals’ Ranks*, the ritual for delivering salvation from karmic roots requires opening an altar on four sides in the central courtyard. Choose an auspicious site for its construction, ideally in grotto-heavens and blessed lands, renowned mountains and tranquil abodes, mysterious altars and Daoist monasteries—places untouched by battlefields, execution grounds, slaughterhouses, prisons, birthing chambers, tombs, or polluted and defiled grounds. Such a site is deemed auspicious.

The orientation must be precise, facing south with the back to the north. If the existing building’s foundation or orientation differs, determine the four directions based on true cardinal points, disregarding minor deviations or reversals. Under no circumstances should the building’s alignment dictate the altar’s orientation.

The method of constructing the altar may involve stacking precious bricks, laying patterned stones, temporarily assembling bamboo or wood, or building with rammed earth—whatever conforms to the prescribed standards to uphold the dignity of the morning memorial. Alternatively, one may erect a Heavenly Treasure Terrace, modeled after the upper realms. When conducting a retreat and pacing the void, the altar takes precedence, as if attending an audience at the Jade Capital Mountain.

The altar should be exposed to the Three Lights (sun, moon, and stars), with a bamboo or wooden frame and a thatched roof. At the altar’s center, an opening is made above to serve as a "heavenly well." A rain shelter may be prepared to guard against wind and rain, but it should not be used in clear weather.

Du Guangcheng stated: Ordinary sentiment favors an open altar, yet sincerity’s resonance transcends the Nine Heavens, while lack of devotion turns even jade steps into barriers. If the cinnabar prohibitions move the perfected immortals and one’s focused intent aligns with the divine, how can mere structures obstruct? After the altar is consecrated, one must not walk backward within it or allow outsiders to profane the sacred. The prohibitions are stringent.

Moreover, as weather is unpredictable, if wind and rain suddenly arise during a memorial presentation, disrupting the solemn and orderly proceedings, causing haste and disorder, the ritual’s beginning and end will be thrown into chaos, and reverence will be entirely lost.

Thus, the Confucians refrain from offering sacrifices when their attire is disordered or their demeanor improper, precisely to guard against such lapses. Judged by this standard, an altar enclosed within a hall allows for unbroken circumambulation from beginning to end, ensuring no breach of ritual decorum and naturally fostering resonance with the divine. The *Yellow Register Simplified Writs* states: The upper tier of the altar shall have four sides and four corners, with upper and lower directions, together forming ten gates, each two *zhang* and four *chi* in width. Beyond these ten gates, open the Heavenly Gate and Earthly Portal, the Sun Gate and Moon Gate, and at the four corners construct a single gate, each three *zhang* and two *chi* in width, called the Four-Boundary General Gates, where the Eight Trigrams inscribed plaques are placed. The scriptures record only two tiers, embodying the principle of modeling heaven and emulating earth. Now, according to the *Guangcheng Ritual Standards*, the altar is built with three tiers: the upper tier two *zhang* and four *chi* square, the middle tier three *zhang* and two *chi* square, and the lower tier four *zhang* square. Alternatively, if the upper tier is one *zhang* and eight *chi*, then the middle tier is two *zhang* and eight *chi*, and the lower tier’s perimeter is only three *chi* wide—this is also permissible. The middle tier must allow space for prostration and kneeling and thus cannot be too narrow. Each tier is typically two *chi* and three *cun* high, or one *chi* and two *cun*, one *chi* and five *cun*, or nine *cun* as a standard. If the terrain is cramped, one may deviate from the prescribed measurements, adjusting the altar’s size and height according to the available space and the hall’s dimensions. Alternatively, on level ground, an altar with only two tiers may suffice. Flexibility is key; one must not be rigid.

For the upper tier’s ten gates, use twenty long *zuan* and ten short *zuan*, along with ten gate plaques. For the middle tier’s western gate, use eight long *zuan* and twenty short *zuan*, with four gate plaques. For the lower tier’s eight gates, use sixteen long *zuan* and sixteen short *zuan*, with eight gate plaques. In total, the three tiers require forty-four long *zuan* and fifty-four short *zuan*. The long *zuan* extend one *zhang* and nine *chi* above ground, while the short ones are seven *chi* and six *cun* embedded in the earth, making ninety-eight *zuan* in all. The *Zhang Qingdu* ritual uses only sixty-four *zuan*, as it has only two tiers, with the Eight Trigrams *zuan* arranged outside the altar. The length of the *zuan* need not be fixed; it may vary according to the hall’s height. When arranging the *zuan*, adjust their spacing to suit the terrain, ensuring uniformity in density. The *zuan* are crafted from wood, lacquered in red, with carved plaques depicting lotus and flaming pearl motifs. The sides of the gates are engraved with images of the sun, moon, and auspicious clouds, all executed with precision. The twenty-two gate plaques are each three *cun* and three *fen* wide and two *cun* and four *fen* long, decorated in the five colors corresponding to their directions and inscribed with gate names.

Between every two *zuan* on all three tiers, mount a lamp holder and fashion five-colored lotus lamps, alternating them. When lit at night, these total ninety-eight lamps. The three tiers of *zuan* are bound with crimson or azure cords, wrapped three times. The first wrapping begins below the floral head of the long *zuan*, encircling the gates. The second wrapping begins below the floral head of the short *zuan*. The third wrapping is placed roughly two *chi* above the second, aligned in height. The second and third wrappings should not obstruct the gates. At the heads of the long *zuan*, cross the cords in a grid pattern and hang small floral branches and banners, alternating them uniformly across all three tiers.

The altar’s surface is covered with thirty-eight sets of woven mats. The outer two tiers are enclosed with twelve bolts of yellow cloth, arranged neatly and with meticulous care. Outside the upper tier’s gates, hang thirty-two Heavenly Banners, their colors corresponding to the directions. At the altar’s center, suspend three Heavenly Banners, and around it hang the Five Directions’ Guardian Spirit Banners. Within the altar, set up a canopy and throne, arranging the seats of the Three Supreme Lords of the Great Dao. Place the sacred scriptures at the center, and around them arrange the altars for the ten directions, each adorned with incense, flowers, and ritual offerings according to their respective directions. Additionally, set up two ritual tables, positioned only at the Heavenly Gate in the *qian* direction, with a single gate for entry and exit, symbolizing heaven. The middle tier is arranged with the positions of the six ranks of officials, with entry and exit restricted to the Earthly Portal in the *xun* direction of the southeast, symbolizing earth. All who ascend the altar to perform the fast and circumambulate must enter and exit through the Earthly Portal; no other gates may be used. The lower tier opens a single gate in the *li* direction for entry and exit. Outside the altar, arrange lamps according to the prescribed method. On the altar, display ritual talismans and standards corresponding to the directions.

Beyond the three tiers, erect floral pillars, each three *chi* or five *chi* high, to demarcate the purified space, with a single gate for entry and exit. The rest are cordoned off with azure cords. For each side of the altar, assign three attendants to maintain ritual decorum, totaling twelve. They must remain orderly and disciplined, without gaps or crowding. When performing the *Step of Emptiness* or circumambulation, they must follow the prescribed sequence. To the left and right of the altar, set up six tents and twelve elevated platforms for administrative duties. For minor fasts, one need not construct an altar with bells and chimes; the rituals may be conducted within the oratory.

Ascending the altar serves as a proxy for the Primordial Beginning’s responsive transformation; thus, one first establishes ritual decorum to govern the myriad heavens. According to the great ritual, the arrangement of gates, the illumination of the four directions, and the lamp diagrams are detailed below.

*Great Tomb Lamps:* 3 (*gong* and *yu* at *chen*; *shang* at *chou*; *jiao* at *wei*; *zhi* at *xu*)
*Lesser Tomb Lamps:* 5 (*gong* and *yu* at *xu*; *shang* at *wei*; *jiao* at *chou*; *zhi* at *chen*)
*Seven Ancestors Lamps:* 7 (southwest direction)
*Nine Dark Realms Lamps:* 9 (alternatively, arranged in eight directions with the center; northeast direction assigned to southwest; nine hell tablets erected above)
*Flanking Gate Lamps:* 2 (opposite the Dao Portal Lamps, placed to the left and right of the gate)
*Twenty-Four Qi Lamps:* 24 (southeast direction)
*Eight Trigrams Lamps:* 8 (arranged in eight directions, each with a tablet)
*Nine Palaces Lamps:* 9 (arranged in eight directions, center assigned to *kun*; aligned with the *Huoluo* Dipper’s nine palaces)
*Ten Directions Lamps:* 10 (arranged in ten directions)
*Twenty-Eight Constellations Lamps:* 28 (beginning at the east, arranged counterclockwise in each direction; seven constellations starting from *Jiao*)
*Thirty-Six Heavens Lamps:* 36 (above Heaven Gate)
*Five Peaks Lamps:* 5 (arranged in four directions, center assigned to the west)

The above lamps total sixteen types, comprising one hundred fifty-nine lamps, each placed according to its direction, as previously detailed. Each lamp is accompanied by a tablet inscribed with its name, such as *Dao Portal Lamp*, *Jiao Constellation Lamp*, *East Wind-Thunder Earth Prison Lamp*, *First Palace Lamp*, *East Direction Lamp*, *Eastern Peak Lamp*, and the like.

In this rite, the *Seven Ancestors Lamps* and *Nine Dark Realms Lamps* are lit in the central courtyard, which may obstruct ritual proceedings. Their directional placements have already been specified above. Additionally, the *Zhaitu Shixian* Altar Diagram by Master Tianju includes *Six Jia*, *Eight Solar Terms*, *Ten Directives*, *Five La*, *Sun Palace*, and *Moon Palace* lamps, though these lack canonical basis. The *Golden Register Simplified Texts* also omit their ritual invocations. Furthermore, the lamp arrangements for the *Five Peaks* and *Seven Ancestors* differ from those described here in bowl counts and diagrams. Rather than altering them, both versions are preserved for consideration by learned scholars.

If the *Twenty-Eight Constellations* lamps are lit according to their stellar configurations, the total reaches three hundred thirteen lamps. The scale should be adjusted according to one’s capacity. Generally, burning incense and lighting lamps are the foremost acts of merit in purification rites. Other matters may be expanded as needed, but these are not discussed here. Only the lamps mirroring heaven and earth should be arranged with utmost generosity.

With reverence, I have consulted astronomical texts to produce these diagrams. May they be carefully examined.

*Guangcheng* states: If the altar space is too narrow to arrange the lamps, they may be placed elsewhere while adhering to the ritual invocations.

**Left Canopy of the Mysterious Master (1):**
The Mysterious Master of Numinous Treasure serves as the Transformative Sovereign of the Three Heavens and the Preceptor of the Teaching’s Expansion. When conducting purification rites, one must first petition and invoke them to witness the merit of the rite. A canopy is erected, and a sacred image, table, and offerings of incense and flowers are arranged according to ritual propriety.

**Right Canopy of the Five Emperors (1):**
The Five Venerable Lords of Highest Sovereignty oversee the records of merit and transgression in heaven, verifying the merit of purification rites. According to ancient protocols, they were placed at the altars of the five directions. The *Guangcheng Rites* now prescribe their separate arrangement north of the Three Masters’ positions, opposite the Mysterious Master, with canopies, tables, and furnishings arranged according to ritual propriety.

**Left Canopy of the Heavenly Master (2):**
The Orthodox Heavenly Master of the One serves as the Dharma Sovereign of the Three Heavens and the Preceptor of Ritual Dispensation. For all purification rites, one must petition and invoke them to expound the teachings according to ritual propriety.

**Right Canopy of the Three Masters (2):**
The Three Masters of Scriptures and Ordinations serve as the Foundational Preceptors of Liberation, embodying the essence of sustaining mindfulness. Their teachings are expounded according to ritual propriety.

**Left Canopy of the Three Officials (3):**
The Three Officials oversee the records of the Three Primes’ examinations, verifying the merit of purification rites. Their teachings are expounded according to ritual propriety.

**Right Canopy of the Purification Overseer (3):**
The Purification Overseer presides over the Numinous Treasure purification rites, supervising the proceedings. Their teachings are expounded according to ritual propriety.

The six canopies above are arranged to the left and right before the Mysterious Altar in sequence. Additionally, there is the canopy for the *Three Masters of Orthodox Unity*, reflecting the reverence for ancestral preceptors at the Orthodox Unity ancestral altar of Mount Longhu. Master Tian, however, incorporated this canopy while placing the *Three Masters of Scriptures and Ordinations* above Heaven Gate, leading to the common but erroneous notion of the *Three Masters of Heaven Gate*. This is not part of the original canon. When conducting Numinous Treasure purification rites, one should adhere to the ancient protocols.

If the space is too narrow to accommodate six canopies, they may be consolidated into three canopies on the left, right, and center. Each canopy is divided into three sections with curtains, and three sets of incense, flowers, and tables are arranged within. All are positioned centrally for mutual veneration and ritual proceedings, with the center as the most honored, the left as secondary, and the right as tertiary.

May this be carefully examined in detail.

**Hall and Terrace Regulations**

The Master said: When establishing a grand purification rite, one must first erect the Twelve Halls and Terraces to summon and assemble the lofty immortals and true spirits, assigning each to their respective offices and sacred stations. The protocols for dispatching, invoking, and praying must be meticulously observed.

1. **Azure Flower Hall (Qinghua Tang)**
   At its center, install the positions of the Azure Mystery Supreme Emperor and the Left and Right Perfected Ones. Above, place the *Chart of the Azure Vault and Empty Songs*. Each day, burn incense and recite three *Hymns of Salvation*, performing the Nine Morning Circuits in reverent procession.

   This hall must be established prior to the preliminary announcement to transmit the *Memorial for Heavenly Salvation*. Erect the Azure Mystery Banner here for ritual proceedings.

2. **Divine Tiger Hall (Shenhu Tang)**
   Following the preliminary announcement, select a chamber at the *Gen* (Northeast) gate. At its center, install the Divine Tiger Lady and her officials. To the left and right, establish the Yin and Yang altars. In the middle, facing upward, set the Eight Gates Summoning Terrace for souls, with the *Summoning Soul Tablets* placed on either side. All matters concerning the issuance of jade missives to summon the deceased are conducted here.

   Some refer to this as the *Mystic Portal of the Divine Tiger*.

3. **Censure Bureau (Jiucha Si)**
   At its center, install the positions of the Five Masters and the Three Officials. The Nine Morning Censures are conducted here.

   If the Six Canopies are already in place, this hall need not be established.

4. **Refinement Hall (Jingsi Tang)**
   Also called the *Hall of True Preservation* or *Hall of Silent Contemplation*.
   At its center, install the position of the Orthodox Unity Heavenly Master and the ancestral masters of the purification rites. A high seat and table are arranged, where the High Merit Master resides, with the six ranks of officials positioned in order. All morning and evening devotions, as well as entries and exits, occur within this chamber.

5. **Netherworld Officials’ Hall (Mingguan Tang)**
   At its center, install the positions of the Ten Kings of Mount Tai and Fengdu, along with all subordinate netherworld bureaus. Arrange them according to their ranks.

6. **Life-Monitoring Bureau (Jiansheng Si)**
   At its center, set the tables for the Nine Heavens’ Perfected Ones, above which the *True Writs of Life-Monitoring* are placed. Summoned souls are brought here for deliverance and healing.

7. **Celestial Physicians’ Hall and Purification Chamber (Tianyi Yuan Danghui Suo)**
   At its center, install the positions of the Celestial Physicians and all attendant transcendent officials, along with the purifying and drying immortals. Summoned souls receive medical treatment and ablutions here.

8. **Refinement-Receiving Bureau (Shoulian Si)**
   At its center, install the positions of the Supreme Emperor and the various honored ones. To the left and right, array the officials and officers of refinement. All rites of transformation and refinement are conducted here.

   If space is too narrow to establish this hall, proceed as scheduled, or arrange the positions of the refinement and deliverance officials to the left and right within the ritual arena, conducting rites at the center. Since the position of the Supreme Emperor is already present in the ritual arena, it need not be duplicated.

9. **Yellow Register Court (Huanglu Yuan)**
   At its center, install the tables for the Perfected Saints of the Yellow Register Court, above which the talismans of the Primordial Beginning and the Divine Empyrean Perfected Ones are placed. The deliverance of suffering souls is its primary function.

10. **Life-Receiving Bureau (Shousheng An)**
    At its center, install the table for the Sacred Position of Life-Receiving, above which the records of judged and destined souls—along with their ranks and destinies—are placed. This bureau is solely responsible for their registration.

11. **Five Paths General Prefecture (Wudao Dufu)**
    At its center, install the positions of the Five Paths deities, who govern the opening and closing of the earth’s gates and the salvation of all classes of wandering souls in the Five Paths.

12. **Memorial-Presenting Bureau (Tongzhang Si)**
    Install the positions of the spirit officials and officers of the *From-Chapter* here, arranging them according to rank. All presentations of memorials and petitions are conducted here.

**Auxiliary Stations**

- **Ritual Inspection Bureau (Ou Lin Suo)**
  Install the positions of the officials and officers of the master’s own methods and all received teachings, along with the attending officers, merit officials, and direct talismans. Arrange them as appropriate on the western side of the altar.

  Alternatively, this may serve as the *Local Domain Bureau* for the earth deity.

  As Du Yi stated: *"Through summons and presentations, resonance is conveyed to the Supreme Mystery."*
  When establishing a ritual arena, the earth deity is paramount. Its position should be set opposite the altar.

  Nowadays, it is also reasonable to include the city gods, local earth deities, and the Five Paths deities of the area in this *Local Domain Bureau*.

- **Nine Ancestors’ Hall as Deliverance Hall (Jiuzu Wei Zuo Shoudu Tang)**
  For the deliverance of the Nine Dark Realms and the purification of the Nine Ancestors, a position should be set opposite the altar. At its center, install the Nine Ancestors and the Seven Generations of kin, arranging them appropriately with offerings of food and drink, all according to protocol.

  As Du Yi stated: *"Establish it in the southeast."*

- **Universal Deliverance Hall (Pudu Tang)**
  Construct an outer enclosure with four gates, each marked with a placard: *Eastern Fragrant Realm*, *Southern Jambudvīpa*, *Western Godānīya*, and *Northern Uttarakuru*. Cover the roof with white cogon grass, and encircle the structure with green curtains. Building it near a wild riverbank is especially auspicious.

  Surround it with earthen walls, evenly painted with cinnabar. At its center, construct a two-tiered platform. On the upper tier, place a water basin containing an iron tablet inscribed with the *Luminous Chapter of the Terrace*. Install the positions of the Six Paths’ wandering souls. On all four sides, arrange offerings of food, wine, and fruit, with a central *Bushel of Nourishment*. Extensively prepare the *Nine Springs and Myriad Sands* for the ghostly multitudes to hasten their rites.

  Erect this on the *Shen* (Monkey) day and dismantle it on the day the altar is dispersed.

- **Retreat Chamber (Jingshi)**
  The place where the High Merit Master visualizes spirits, inscribes talismans, and writes registers. At its center, install the Perfected Sovereign of the Yellow Register and the transcendent officials of the register’s central canon. Arrange them appropriately. This chamber must be established after the preliminary announcement.

- **Scripture-Recitation Hall (Songjing Tang)**
  At its center, install the position of the Three Treasures. From the day of the preliminary announcement and the gathering of the alliance, the recitation of scriptures, mantras, and sacred titles, as well as the rites of repentance, are conducted here.

- **Soul-Gathering Prefecture (Juhun Fu)**
  At its center, install the positions of the Five Sovereigns of Universal Soul-Gathering, who are solely responsible for assembling the souls of the deceased and summoning the *qi* of the true and living.

**Protocol for Ritual Guards (Yiwei Zhang)**
The Master said: When establishing halls and terraces, the prohibitions and taboos are strict.

Fourteen talismanic seals shall be employed to guard the numinous spirits and pacify the four directions.

When inscribing them, recite two secret incantations, invoke the Jade Purity mudra, and draw the primordial azure, yellow, and white *qi* from the Gate of Heaven, then blow it upon the talismans. These may be transcribed onto boards and hung around the altar’s perimeter, or written and burned as needed.

**Talisman of the Vermilion Chariot and Green Palanquin**
With cinnabar ink and empowered brush, adorn and array the sacred emblems—radiant essences intermingling. The chariot and palanquin traverse the winds, their feathered canopies and jade wheels resplendent.

**Talisman of the Feathered Canopy of Primordial Origin**
The ancestral *qi* congeals, the root of chaos and beginning. Ten revolutions return the numinous, its brilliance unfurling.

**Talisman of the Vermilion Phoenix**
The vermilion phoenix harnesses the carriage, dispelling defilement and manifesting might. The Four Numinous Beasts quake in submission as it soars, its resplendent fan trailing.

**Talisman of the Mystic Dragon**
The five-hued mystic dragon leaps and treads the great void. With brush and inception, it commands the rushing surge, its ninefold hues arrayed in majesty.

**Talisman of the Nine-Colored Standard**
Its halberd gleams with precious light, transforming under the Empty Sovereign. Pure Yang coalesces into Sanskrit, its blossoms scattering across the purple hall.

**Talisman of the Ten Absolute Numinous Banners**
The whirlwind encampment surges, its precious light diffusing. Its radiance outshines the sun, and the myriad sages gaze in reverence.

**Talisman of the Nine Phoenixes in Unison**
The primordial *qi* disperses, vast as clouds and rosy dawn. The nine phoenixes chant in harmony.

**Talisman of the Eight Simurghs in Chorus**
The sevenfold *qi* swirls, encircling Kunlun. The eight simurghs sing as one.

**Talisman of the Five-Colored Lions**
The myriad defilements are crushed and subdued; the ten thousand beasts gaze in awe. It strides alone, fearless, its mighty presence universally bestowed. Immeasurable grace and boundless strength are dispensed, as it sits upright at the center, receiving the Dao in effortless serenity.

**Talisman of the Nine-Light White Cranes**
In accord with the Dao, it delights in radiance, its light illuminating the ten directions. Opening the light atop its crown, the feathered cranes soar, circling the distant Great Void, their whistles and chants heralding auspicious signs.

**Talisman of the Azure Dragon Attendant**
The Supreme Mystery and Luminance expound the Dharma in the forest of transcendence. The Three Realms attend in guard; the eight directions’ mighty spirits render me naturally empowered. Demonic spirits are bound, merging with the Dao in truth. Wondrous *qi* weaves to its end, transforming into dragon form.

**Talisman of the White Tiger’s Guardianship**
The sevenfold *qi* align in response; the great law harmonizes with the flourishing. The celestial patterns of the supreme Dharma congeal *qi* into form. The Five Emperors observe in unison, their jade tablets and primordial purity sealed. The White Tiger guards, the altar’s numinous splendor resplendent.

**Talisman of the Vermilion Bird’s Solar Essence**
The immortal Dao is naturally auspicious; the Highest Purity and numinous clarity ascend. Luminous *qi* soars in four directions, forging life in the Vermilion Mound. The solar *qi* gathers, its resplendent mystery blazing. The Vermilion Bird shields and upholds the eternal Dao.

**Talisman of the Dark Warrior’s Rear Guard**
Amidst the myriad transformations in the void, its towering might subdues the ten thousand heavens. Receiving the mandate of the Supreme Blade, its profound vastness unites the forms of tortoise and serpent.

**Talisman for Summoning the Five Directions’ Attendant Officers and Soldiers to Guard the Altar**
The Master said: These six talismans may summon the five directions’ fivefold numinous spirits, the attendant officers and soldiers of all heavens, and the five directions’ Celestial Emperors with their attendant green-clad officials and soldiers.

In all ritual procedures and recitations of incantations, visualize the various heavens of each direction descending in state, their golden light resplendent across the great void. The Celestial Emperors and their attendants descend through the air, their rare fragrance pervading the expanse. These may be transcribed onto boards and hung to guard the ritual altar.

**True Talisman of the Nine Numinous Wondrous Scenery of the Primordial Essence of the Beginning Light**
Inscribe this talisman in vermilion on blue paper, facing the east with the *qi* of Zhen, and burn it to summon the ninefold *qi* of the Azure Numinous heavens and their attendant officers and soldiers.

**True Talisman of the Great Brahma of the Blazing Vermilion Light Ascending and Pervading the Numinous**
Inscribe this talisman in black on red paper, facing the south with the *qi* of Wu, and burn it to summon the threefold *qi* of the Vermilion Numinous heavens and their attendant officers and soldiers.

**True Talisman of the Sevenfold *Qi* of the Serene Radiance of the White Splendor**
Inscribe this talisman in black on white paper, facing the west with the *qi* of You, and burn it to summon the sevenfold *qi* of the Luminous Numinous heavens and their attendant officers and soldiers.

**True Talisman of the Mystic Treasure of the Serene Scenery of the Mysterious Light**
Inscribe this talisman in vermilion on black paper, facing the north with the *qi* of Zi, and burn it to summon the fivefold *qi* of the Mysterious Numinous heavens and all their hosts of mighty spirits.

**True Talisman of the Precious Light of the Brahma *Qi* of the Empty Sovereign’s Mystic Pervasion**
Inscribe this talisman in black on yellow paper, using the Celestial Master’s mudra with the eastern *qi*, and burn it at the center to summon the twelvefold *qi* of the Yellow Numinous heavens and their attendant officers and soldiers.

**Supreme True Talisman of the Great One of the Wondrous Ultimate of the Highest Dawn**
Inscribe this talisman in vermilion on yellow paper, using the Jade Purity mudra with the southern *qi*, and burn it facing the void to summon the Celestial Emperors of the five directions and their attendant officers, scribes, soldiers, and riverine barriers.

Here ends *The Supreme Purity Numinous Treasure Great Dharma*, Scroll Thirty-Two.
*Supreme Purity Numinous Treasure Great Dharma*, Scroll Thirty-Three.

**The Illuminating and Suffering-Relieving Perfected of Profound Mystery, Ning Quanzhen, Transmitted to the Supreme Three Caverns Disciple, the Lingbao Lineage Master Wang Qizhen, Compiled**

**Section on Ritual Altar Diagrams: Banners, Canopies, and Talismans**

The Master said: For every altar, each banner must bear one talisman, inscribed strictly according to the prescribed method. No other methods may be intermixed.

**Talismans for the Five Directions’ Protective Spirit Banners**
- **East**
- **South**
- **West**
- **North**
- **Center**

Inscribe these five talismans on the front of the banners for the five directions of the Mystic Altar. Only the southern talisman is written in black; the rest are in vermilion.

Recite the **Five Directions’ Protective Spirit Incantation** while inscribing, for this is the *qi* of the Ninefold Azure Heavens.

This talisman derives from *The Cavern Abyss Protective Spirit Incantation Register*.

**Talismans for the Five Directions’ Altar-Guarding**
- **Eastern Azure Emperor Incantation**
  Nine *qi* sprout in yang,
  Jade calendar’s dragon script.
  The Eight Trigrams spread without,
  One virtue hides within.
  Transformation arises from me,
  Death and decay reverse to auspice.

- **Southern Vermilion Emperor Incantation**
  Southern mound’s triple lights,
  *Qi* fills, radiance blazes.
  Nurturing and rectifying,
  No evil can withstand.
  Vermilion fire, stone fire—
  Commanded by me.

- **Western White Emperor Incantation**
  Great White’s flowing essence,
  Seven stars guard the numinous.
  Qian’s virtue inwardly preserved,
  Metal and fire cannot harm.
  What life cannot transform,
  White Prime employs its brightness.

- **Northern Black Emperor Incantation**
  Mystic virtue’s five numina,
  Salvation’s primordial unity.
  Embryonic essence joins demons,
  Inwardly pervading the seven.
  Yin fire inwardly revolves,
  Mystic virtue transforms to clarity.
  Drowning ghosts and bandits,
  Slay and extinguish evil spirits.

- **Central Yellow Emperor Incantation**
  Central Lord of all spirits,
  Twelve primordial perfected.
  Governing the four great,
  Primordial Jade Dawn.
  **Incantation**
  Mystic Emperor, High Perfected,
  Primordial Five Elders.
  Inscribe talismans, transmit teachings,
  Enable me to practice the Dao.
  Today is the time,
  Transmit the true, confer the Dao.
  *Establish the retreat* (amend to: *Establish the retreat and practice the Dao*).
  Summon spirits, bind demons,
  Disasters and calamities sweep away.
  Five Directions’ great spirits,
  Reverently submit to the Three Treasures.
  Those who follow me prosper,
  Ultimately attaining agelessness.
  Escape death, enter life,
  Flourishing yet unaging.
  Those who defy me perish,
  Living, they meet hardship;
  Dying, they descend to the Dark Capital,
  Tortured in hell.

Place the four directional talismans at the four gates, and the central talisman at the door of the retreat hall. Burn incense and pray:

*"Let the two Direct Talisman Officers of the [X] Emperor emerge. Today, the duty officer [Name] and his retinue of [Number] attendants, six dragons, each in strict attire, holding jade and bearing tablets, ascend to the imperial court. We submit this talisman to initiate the matter. From this moment until the Dao-practice concludes, ensure all is orderly and nothing is omitted."*

Proceed accordingly. Only in the last month of each season is the Yellow Emperor used; otherwise, follow the Five Emperors.

Alternatively, inscribe these five talismans on the reverse of the five directional banners.

Cai Zhixu and Lu Shizhong used these when borrowing land to establish altars.

*The Three Supreme Departments’ Talismans* call these the **Residence-Guarding Talismans**, inscribed on boards to guard the five directions. They originate from *The Lingbao Scripture of Ascending Mystery*.

**Three Heavens Banner**
**Thirty-Two Heavens Banner**

The Master said: Each banner should measure either three feet and two inches or two feet and four inches. The eastern banner has eight green heads, the southern eight red, the western eight white, and the northern eight black. Alternatively, following the method of *The Scripture of Salvation Through the Degrees of Humanity*, use the nine colors—yellow, green, blue, red, dark green, black, purple, and white—arranged in sequence from the Heaven of Supreme Sovereignty. This is also permissible.

On the front of the banner, inscribe the titles of the Heavenly Emperors; on the reverse, seal the talismans of the Thirty-Two Heavens. These originate from *The Great Kalpa Scripture of Numinous Treasure*, differing from the rites of *The Supreme Perfected Regulations for the Numinous Treasure Nine Heavens Life-Safeguarding and Destiny-Preserving Retreat*. The talismans of the Thirty-Two Heavens are found in the section on talismanic script in the scriptures.

**Azure Mystery Treasure Canopy**
The Master said: When making a preliminary announcement, first erect the Azure Mystery Canopy. The method requires azure silk measuring forty-nine feet. Construct a top crown to form a great treasure canopy, fashioned with eight corners, from which hang eight small banners. In the center, suspend a large banner to complete the treasure canopy, aligning it with the nine provinces’ astrological divisions. On the banner’s body, seal the Great Nine Dragons Talisman in realgar, with the legs spread apart. Seal the Azure Mystery Treasure Proclamation Talisman between the feet, and inscribe the intent of the retreat on the two hands. Hang it from a tall pole. This serves to communicate with Heaven, deliver the suffering, announce to the ten directions, and halt trials for the imprisoned.

Another method states: The Supreme Unity Treasure Banner is made of yellow silk and may also be inscribed with talismans following this pattern. The Nine Dragons Talisman and the Azure Palace Treasure Harmony are both found in the section on talismanic script in the retreat methods.

**Oath-Announcing Treasure Banner**
The Master said: When establishing a grand retreat, first erect the Oath-Announcing Banner. Make it of double-layered yellow silk, also forty-nine feet in length. On the banner’s body, seal the August Title of the Jade Emperor—*Jade Emperor, Great Heavenly Worthy, Mysterious Lofty High Sovereign*—in ten characters at the center, and inscribe the intent of the retreat on the two hands. Hang it from a tall pole in an open space before the altar. This announces to the boundless heavens, pledges alliance with the Three Realms, and pre-announces the retreat’s schedule, serving as a pledge for the period of merit-building. Thus, the hidden and obscure are made manifest, and gods and spirits gaze from afar, as the ritual objects and forms are displayed.

Another method: At the top, write: *“Your servant respectfully submits”* in five characters. On the body, inscribe: *“The Supreme, Boundless Dao; the Utmost True, Primordial Supreme; the Thirty-Six Sections of the Venerable Scriptures; the True Writ and Treasure Talismans of the Three Supreme Worthies; the Ten Directions’ Hosts of Sages; the Great Dharma Master of the Mysterious Center; the Officials and Attendants of the Three Realms; all mighty numina—humbly beseech your radiant grace to witness this retreat’s affairs”*—forty-nine characters in total. On the two hands and feet, inscribe the ranks of the Dharma, adapting to the practitioner’s intent. The August Title of the Jade Emperor is found in the section on talismanic script in the retreat methods.

The Banner for Translocating Spirits and Returning to the Yellow Treasure

The Master says: When establishing the Nine Dark Prisons, one must first erect the Banner for Translocating Spirits and Returning to the Yellow, positioned to the east of the altar. The method employs white and yellow silk, layered together and fashioned into a banner forty-nine feet in length. Inscribe the talismans according to the prescribed form, then suspend it aloft where the wind may freely stir it. The lonely souls and suffering spirits of the Ten Directions and Nine Dark Realms, upon beholding this banner and the direction its tassels point, shall have their myriad torments dissolved and swiftly awaken to their virtuous nature. If they raise their voices in praise, the merit before humans and heavens shall be most profound, revering the precious treasure and venerating it to fulfill wondrous fruition.

Another method: On the two hands, inscribe the Heavenly Worthies of the Ten Directions, five on each side. Beneath the left hand, write *Savior of Suffering Perfected* and *Great Compassion Perfected*; beneath the right hand, write *Remover of Transgressions Perfected* and *Deliverer Perfected*. On the two feet, inscribe the *Sweet Dew Mantra*. The use remains the same.

*Returning to Radiant Brilliance Banner*

The Master says: For all constructions of the Wheel Lamp of Returning Radiance, the Banner of Returning Radiance is always erected to the southeast of the wheel. The method requires crimson silk, thirty-six feet in length, doubled and fashioned, with cinnabar and orpiment ground together to inscribe the talismans on both front and back according to the prescribed pattern. On the front, either inscribe in seal script the ten characters of *Compassionate Transforming Lord, Treasure Banner, Welcoming and Guiding Heavenly Worthy*, and suspend it high in the void. When the dark and hidden souls of the ten directions behold this numinous banner, with a single thought of refuge, the winds arise, and the dust-labor of transgressive hindrances and grave offenses are all absolved and dissolved, allowing ascent to the Southern Palace.

**Prison Lamps Diagram Chapter**
Transmitted by Dongwei Gaoshi, Illuminating and Salvation-Aiding Perfected Lord Ning Quanzhen, to the Shangqing Three Caverns Disciple, Lingbao Preceptor and Lineage Master Wang Qizhen

The Master says: Whenever establishing a grand fast, one must break through darkness and continue illumination, open and release all prisons, and pardon all sinful souls. Arrange according to the diagrams and methods as prescribed below.

**Nine Goblets and Nine Mounds Lamp Diagram**
The Master says: For the salvation rite, lamps should be fashioned into a tree according to proper method. Beneath it, establish the Wheel of Heaven and Earth—round to symbolize Heaven, square to symbolize Earth. Divide the three luminaries to illuminate the nine mounds, array the eight extremities to center the August One. From the deceased’s initial passing through the seven sevens, ensure the lamp light continues unbroken to pierce the gates of darkness.

The method for constructing the lamp tree: Use catalpa wood to craft a single lamp tree, dividing its top into nine goblets, each holding one lamp. Below, form a three-tiered altar of pure earth, round above and square below. On the upper tier, place the lamp tree, from which hang nine-headed banners. On the middle tier, erect the Nine Qi Tablets and set nine lamps. On the lower tier, establish the Nine Mounds August Lords’ tablets and set nine lamps. The three tiers together hold twenty-seven lamps. Outside, arrange the Eight Trigrams and Eight Gates, lighting eight lamps to illuminate above the Nine Heavens, through the Nine Wilds, and below the Nine Mounds. The light converges into nine pathways, extending outward to the Eight Extremities, encircling the ten directions. In total, thirty-five lamps represent the thirty-five divisions of primordial qi, the method of the Supreme Mystery.

**Nine Dark Prisons Diagram**
The Master says: Model Heaven and emulate Earth, forming the pattern with square and round.

**Nine Dark Ministries: Overseers of Sin and Judgment**

The Nine Dark Ministries govern transgressions and decrees, their jurisdiction encompassing the Luo and Deng regions, with their seat in the southeast at the *si* earthly branch. According to the statutes of the Supreme One and the Sacred Perfected, nine altars of sand and soil are constructed, each two feet square. The nine altars together form a single whole, totaling six feet in breadth, modeling Earth’s yin and embodying the extreme of the two-six configuration. Each altar is shaped with four corners and three bends, resembling the form of a prison. Within each prison, three lamps are lit, making twenty-seven lamps in total across the nine prisons. At the heart of each prison, a tablet is erected according to its directional alignment. On the front of each tablet is inscribed the *Breaking the Earth Prisons Talisman*—refer to the *Talisman Gate of the Purification Rites* for its form. On the reverse is written the prison’s name, and above each tablet hangs one of the nine banners. The design is detailed in the *Seal-Cover Chapter*. Additionally, nine yellow banners are prepared, each inscribed with the *Nine Heavens’ Life-Generating Chapter Talisman*. When the nine prisons are broken, the nine banners are burned, and these yellow banners are then hung in their place. First, the *Yellow Banner for Guiding Spirits* is erected, allowing the dark souls to behold it, whereby all myriad sins are extinguished.

The Nine Dark Prisons reside in the central palace of the Eight Trigrams. According to the division of the Nine Provinces, each is overseen by its local earth deity. In Heaven, they correspond to the Nine Heavens; on Earth, to the Nine Palaces; and in transformation, they take the form of the Nine Dark Prisons. Though they bear nine names, all arise from a single *qi* and are summoned by a single thought. For every evil thought harbored by the deceased, the corresponding prison manifests, and retribution follows. Thus, the Most High, in boundless compassion, established these purification rites to deliver and uplift suffering souls—know well their origin:

1. **Dark Nether (幽冥)**: Transformed from the nine *qi* of the eastern *Zhen* trigram. All burgeoning life and stirring creatures await the awakening of wind and thunder, hence its name: *Wind and Thunder*.
2. **Dark Yin (幽阴)**: Transformed from the three *qi* of the southern *Li* trigram. Fire reaches its utmost yang, giving rise to the way of extreme yang generating yin, hence its name: *Fire’s Veil*.
3. **Dark Night (幽夜)**: Transformed from the seven *qi* of the western *Dui* trigram. The light of a single day vanishes at the *you* earthly branch, embodying the way of metal’s unyielding slaughter, hence its name: *Vajra*.
4. **Dark Feng (幽酆)**: Transformed from the five *qi* of the northern *Kan* trigram. The *qi* of the season and the number of water culminate at *zi*, where yin reaches its extreme and yang begins to stir, and water flourishes at *zi*, hence its name: *Bitter Cold*.
5. **Dark Capital (幽都)**: Transformed from the *fan qi* of the northeastern *Gen* trigram. The *qi* of the season arrives at *yin* and *gen*, embodying the principle of gentle warmth and generative bestowal, born of wood’s *qi*, hence its name: *Scalding Waters*.
6. **Dark Governance (幽治)**: Transformed from the *fan qi* of the southeastern *Xun* trigram. Fire reaches its zenith at *si*, where all things blaze with molten brilliance, hence its name: *Bronze Pillars*.
7. **Dark Barrier (幽关)**: Transformed from the *fan qi* of the southwestern *Kun* trigram. Metal’s *qi* brings the stern killing force of the southwest, and as it reaches the gateway of human life, it often gives rise to punitive and destructive intent, hence its name: *Slaughter and Dissection*.
8. **Dark Court (幽府)**: Transformed from the *fan qi* of the northwestern *Qian* trigram, embodying the turning wheel of Heaven, hence its name: *Fire Chariot*.
9. **Dark Prison (幽狱)**: Transformed from the central *qi*, governed by the Earth Sovereign of the central palace, serving as the overarching administration of the center, hence its name: *Universal Torment*.

The establishment of the Nine Prisons is fundamentally for the universal deliverance of the sunken and lost. If conducting a minor rite—without invoking blessings for the sovereign and the realm above, or delivering the nine ancestors and the six paths below, but merely liberating one or two souls—how could the Celestial Emperor issue a special pardon and open all nine prisons for the sake of a single individual? Such a notion defies reason. Though all earthly prisons may be broken and all dark souls delivered, if one’s intent lacks even the slightest merit of benefiting others, it contradicts the very purpose of this ritual. If the aim is solely to offer prayers, lighting lamps and reciting invocations—or performing rites like the *Nine Goblets of Lamps*—suffices. The *Breaking the Prisons* ritual need not be undertaken, lest one risk presumption and disrespect.

Yet, for filial children repaying their parents, sincerity and repentance of sins are enough—how could one assume their ancestors must have fallen into hell and thus perform this rite? Such reasoning is misplaced. If one truly wishes to proceed, one should provide *hulu* offerings to deliver the wandering souls as circumstances allow, building merit according to one’s capacity. Then, the *Breaking the Prisons* ritual may be performed without apprehension. For countless suffering souls, lost in the depths of delusion, a single misguided thought may consign them to these prisons forever. Without beseeching Heaven’s decree, enacting talismans, and breaking the prisons, how could they attain liberation? Thus, the ritual must be conducted according to the prescribed method.

**Returning Radiance Lamp Diagram**

The Master said: The *Alliance of the True* ritual canon contains the *Returning Radiance Descending Light* method, a rite for repentance and deliverance from the Five Accumulations and the Gates of Suffering. A wheel of catalpa wood is fashioned in the likeness of a chariot axle. On its upper tier, twelve lamps are lit; on the middle tier, sixteen; and on the lower tier, twenty-one—with the Five Accumulations and Gates of Suffering at the center, making forty-nine in total. Tablets are erected bearing the names of the various hells. Additionally, forty-nine small banners of yellow and white are made, their colors alternating as they are planted in sequence. First, the *Returning Radiance Banner* must be raised in the southeast of the wheel, aligning inner and outer correspondences, for the *Yellow Register’s* broad deliverance of imprisoned souls. By amassing this merit, one dedicates it to the deceased, enabling the light of the Three Luminaries to bend and illuminate the gates of the Nine Springs. Thus, iron cities melt away, blades and poisons lose their edge, suffering souls are delivered, and all behold the Three Lights, swiftly reborn among humans and devas. This is the original ritual method, long abandoned and unused. It should now follow the models of Cai Zhixu and Lu Shizhong: three concentric enclosures of sand are arranged, square without and round within, resembling a chariot wheel with a diameter of nine feet. The outer ring has twenty-four spokes, with twenty-four lamps lit and twenty-four hell tablets erected. The middle ring has fifteen spokes, with fifteen lamps lit and tablets for the Five Accumulations, Five Paths, and Five Gates of Suffering. The inner ring has nine spokes, with nine lamps lit and tablets for the Three Evil Gates, Three Corpse Paths, and Three Realms of Bondage. At the center, a single *Returning Radiance Spirit Banner* is planted, with one lamp lit. Again, forty-nine small banners of alternating yellow and white are made and arranged beside the lamps. Once the repentance lamps are completed, they are burned atop the lamps. **Chariot Axle Wheel Design**

The Master said: South of the Great Iron Encirclement Mountain lies the Gorge Stone Hell. Its form is entirely black, flanked by flames, with a blood pool beneath, situated within a vast stone to the southeast. Broad above and tapering below, a fissure opens at its center, through which sinners pass, drenched in a hundred toxic medicinal brews that scour body and heart. This hell is called the Blood Pool, where women who died in childbirth sink for kalpas, their suffering beyond measure, their defilement extreme. Within dwell millions of ghostly soldiers who torment day and night—beings such as the Body-Flipping Great Spirit, the Corpse-Hurling Great Spirit, and the Heart-Eating, Brain-Devouring Ghost Kings.

**Diagram of the Thirty-Two Heavens Lamp**

The Master said: The lamp altar is constructed in three tiers. The upper tier represents the Four Formless Heavens, where the throne of the Formless Realm Demon King is established, and banners of the Ten Directions’ Flying Heavenly Spirit-Kings are hung. The middle tier encompasses the Eighteen Heavens, where the throne of the Form Realm Demon King is set. The lower tier honors the Ten Directions’ Heavenly Worthies, where the throne of the Desire Realm Demon King is placed. At the altar’s heart stands a banner inscribed with the Great Demon King of the Three Realms.

The Master said: This diagram follows the primordial unity of the cosmic net’s unfolding. Above hang the banners of the Thirty-Two Heavens; externally, eight gates are opened, and the tablets of the Twenty-Eight Constellations are arrayed around the perimeter.

**Diagram of the Nine Heavens Lamp**

The Master said: The Nine Heavens Lamp is also called the Nine-Cup Lamp. If a lamp tree is not used, it may be laid out upon the ground. According to the *Cavern Scriptures*, the First Heaven resides at the center, directly above; the Second Heaven lies to the south; the Third to the southeast; the Fourth to the west; the Fifth to the northeast; the Sixth to the northwest; the Seventh to the north; the Eighth to the southwest; and the Ninth to the east. Nine qi tablets are also placed according to direction, with the banners of the Nine Heavens suspended above. The arrangement must adhere strictly to this diagram. Those who begin with the First Heaven in the northeast act contrary to principle—this must be carefully examined.

**The Mysterious and Venerable Gate of the Divine Tiger**

The Master said: The supreme Dao of the Numinous Treasure takes as its foremost duty the salvation of the hidden and the suffering in the nether realms. Through the accumulation of merit and the cultivation of conduct, one embodies the boundless compassion of the Primordial Beginning, whose essential aim is the deliverance of all beings.

Among all methods, the Gate of Summoning and Seizing is the most exalted. When the yin-corpses sink into the eternal night of the underworld, never to behold the light of the sun, one must perform the rites of deliverance and practice this great Dharma.

The Primordial Qi of the Origin, the Chaos Red Script, the Jade Tablets, and the Golden Talismans first gather the yin and yang, harmonizing the Four Images. Through the union of the feminine and masculine, Kan and Li, male and female are distinguished. Thus, the pure ascends and the turbid congeals, and the profound principle is awakened and illuminated. Then, with the Qi of the Northern Culmen, the Five Agents are set in motion. Only then may one approach the Mysterious Altar, settle and clarify the root-source, and attain a state of utter detachment. Ascending to the Southern Heaven, one refines the being with the Primordial Qi of the Three Heavens, thereby transforming and completing the person.

The Heavenly One of the Northern Foundation and the Purple Script of the Great One possess the Great Culmen Palace of the Central Dipper, overseen by the Seven Primes of the Dark and Mysterious Lady, also known as the deity presiding over the Mysterious Elixir of the Great One. Her station is exalted among the Nine Heavens, and she oversees all spirits, serving as the chief administrator of the nether bureaus in the great Dharma of summoning and seizing. All living beings in the Nine Earths, all souls and spirits in life and death, are governed by her.

For those in the Lower Realm whose destinies and lifespans are nearing their end, they fall under the jurisdiction of the Dark and Mysterious. Only when the Lady of the Dipper transmits the talismans to the Mountain Mansion may their souls be pursued and retrieved—this is the office of the Death Registry Bureau. Below her, seven Jade Maidens preside over life and death, each managing the records according to the determinations made at birth. All wandering souls and wayward spirits are under their command.

There are two Great Saints of the Divine Tiger, male and female, who govern the souls of kings, nobles, officials, and commoners throughout the world. Each is attended by twelve thousand spirit-officers who carry out their commands. Among them are three Messengers of Soul-Pursuit, who communicate the decrees of the Great One. Bearing the Jade Tablets of the Dark and Mysterious and the Uniting Talismans of the Great One, they ascend to all heavens and descend to the Three Primes, reaching every true office, the bureaus of water and fire, the courts that examine and punish the underworld, and the agencies that pursue and retrieve souls.

This Dao is not revealed to the mediocre. Since its emergence from the Bi-Lu Grotto, only the Perfected Liu obtained the supreme Dao, and Ye Jing attained the middle. Thus, this transmission is proclaimed. It is not to be compared with the great Dao of the Central Dipper’s Great Culmen, which pursues and seizes the souls of spirits—of ten thousand attempts, not one succeeds. Within it lies the method of summoning and commanding through universal seizing, where recitation in seated meditation may bring immediate results.

When practicing the ranks of the Divine Tiger, one must seek the great Dharma with precision, lest the nether realms be misled.

**The Mysterious Standards of the Five Dippers**

The Master said: The Lord of Life-Allotment of the Eastern Dipper is the palace of the Qi of Blue Yang’s generation, governed by the Heavenly Lord of the Nine Qi of the Blue Numinous Primordial Elder.

The Lord of Name-Recording of the Western Dipper is the palace of the White Numinous’ nurturing of simplicity, governed by the White Numinous Primordial Elder.

The Lord of Life-Generation of the Southern Dipper is the Great Abyss Palace of the Vermilion Flame and Cinnabar Numinous, governed by the Cinnabar Numinous Perfected Elder.

The Lord of Death-Falling of the Northern Dipper is the palace of the Dark and Extinguished Center Harmony, governed by the Five Numinous Mysterious Elder.

The Great Culmen of the Central Dipper is the palace that oversees all spirits, governed by the Yellow Numinous August Elder.

The Lord of Life-Allotment of the Eastern Dipper: When a person receives the One Qi and is born, the Five Thearchs oversee the life-monitoring and destiny-determining offices, fixing the allotment and inscribing the register. Greatness becomes longevity, and smallness becomes a lifespan. All people in the world are allotted one hundred and twenty years of life. Three days are counted as one *suan*, and one hundred and twenty *suan* are calculated as one year. One lifespan is one cycle, and twelve years make one thousand two hundred *suan*. If the life-monitoring office determines that one’s merit and virtue are great, a memorial is made to the sovereign to increase the allotment—greatly by three hundred and sixty *suan*, or minimally by one hundred and twenty *suan*. If the life-monitoring office determines that one’s sins and transgressions are full, the allotment is reduced. If the sins remain unexpiated, the allotment is erased, and the years are diminished or the lifespan shortened, each according to its degree, without the slightest discrepancy.

The Lord of Life-Allotment of the Eastern Dipper is overseen by the Star of the Responsible Wolf. The life chapters of men and women, their forms, virtues, and transgressions, are all recorded by the Lord of Name-Recording of the Western Dipper, overseen by the Star of the Giant Gate. The spirits are divided and descend as darkness, determining poverty, wealth, nobility, and lowliness, and transforming life in the Middle Kingdom—all are under the jurisdiction of the Lord of Life-Generation of the Southern Dipper, overseen by the Stars of Wealth and Literary Brilliance. The transgressions and sins of one’s life, the shortening of years and lifespan, and the permanent severance of destiny and fortune, leading to death and the long night, are all governed by the Lord of Death-Falling of the Northern Dipper, overseen by the Star of the Martial Brilliance.

From life to death, from the recording of names to the allotment of lifespans, from generation to falling, all are overseen by the Great Culmen of the Central Dipper, governed by the Star of the Ruinous Army and the Heavenly Manifestation. The Five Thearchs of the Mysterious Offices determine the destinies of the ten directions of the world and the souls of the four births and six destinies.

Thus, the Heavenly Worthy of the Primordial Beginning established the Palace of the Mysterious Standards, where the Seven Primes Star Lords reside. Each is attended by Divine Tiger generals and officers, along with the Ladies of the Great One, who manage the seals of the Divine Tiger’s soul and spirit. Below them, the Jade Maiden Ladies oversee the registers, administer life and death, and govern the affairs of souls and spirits. If there is any disobedience or negligence, the Ladies of the Great One memorialize the Dipper Palace, which then flies a report to the Jade Emperor. Rewards and punishments are meted out with perfect impartiality, without the slightest partiality.

Those who practice these rites must not be ignorant of these matters.

The Seven Yin Ladies of the Northern Dipper’s Great One and Dark and Mysterious: the Dark and Mysterious Inner Consort Lady, the Purple Prime Lady of the Great One, the Heavenly One of the Northern Foundation Lady, the Jade Tablet Lady of the Divine Tiger, and the Primordial Divine Tiger Lady.

Two Great Saints of the Divine Tiger.

The Divine Tiger’s Offices (continued)

The Male Left Master Cao governs the Three Hun and the hundred joints, presiding over the Hun as the Chief Great Saint He □. The Female Right Wuluán Division guards the Seven Po and the blood-qi, presiding over the Po as the Official Great Saint Qiao □. Both Saints wear crimson robes, their faces the color of jujubes, holding jade tablets and treading in shoes, appearing as kings. They exclusively oversee the celestial stars and the hun-souls of kings, nobles, scholars, and commoners. The term "Divine Tiger" refers to the Heavenly Emperor’s office that governs the hun, namely the Divine Tiger Great Saints. To their left and right are fifteen Flying Talisman Summoning-Po Envoys.

3. Third Jade Maiden Wang Zhenqing, who oversees the hun of those who die from epidemics and miasmic diseases.

6. Sixth Jade Maiden Chang Daoren, who oversees the hun of those who die from miscarriage, childbirth, injury, or bloodshed.
7. Seventh Jade Maiden Dong Xiqing, who oversees the hun of those who die in darkness, by wrongful lightning, or through ghostly delusion.

All the above wear fish-sleeved robes, phoenix crowns, vermilion shoes, feathered skirts with jade pendants, and hold the Registers of Life and Death, governing the hun of the living and the dead, whether compliant or rebellious.

The Divine Tiger’s Seals
The Master says: For every Divine Tiger jade talisman, there must be a corresponding seal, which must be consecrated before use. A talisman without a seal is like an army without a general; a seal without a talisman is like a general without an army. Without both talisman and seal, the pacing of the stars and the summoning of spirits will lack efficacy. Thus, in the Lingbao rites, perfection is prized, and no one has heard of success when these are violated.

The Seals:
- Northern Dipper Dark and Vast Office Seal
- Male Left Seal
- Female Right Seal
- Divine Tiger Jade Tablet Seal
- Divine Tiger General Seizing Seal
- Great Dipper General Monitoring Seal

All the above seals are detailed in the section on Seal Scripts and Models.

The Rite of Consecrating the Seals
The Method says: Use tea, wine, and seasonal fruits in nine portions, arranged on the ninth auspicious day within a purified chamber, and consecrate them according to the ritual.

The Seal Consecration Incantation:
"Northern Foundation of Heaven’s One,
Purple Prime of the Great One.
Dark and Vast Northern Dipper,
Divine Tiger Dark Elder.
Great Saints of the Dipper,
Jade Maidens who pursue hun.
Ten Directions’ essence and light,
Descend with me in spirit.
With each breath and inhalation,
Enter my seal.
Emerge with the qi,
Move with the qi.
Transforming into millions,
Primal, prosperous, harmonious, steadfast.
Swiftly, swiftly, as the Divine Tiger decrees!"

Recite this incantation fourteen times while facing north, then inhale twelve breaths and blow upon the seal. Visualize nine strands of purple-dark qi descending from beneath the Northern Dipper into the seal. Imagine all the generals following the incense smoke, riding the purple-dark qi, and entering the seal. Bow twice and recite the incantation again. Upon completion, pour wine over the seal, cover it with a clean basin, and burn four portions of spirit money atop the seal.

Next, store it in a clean place, encase it in a crimson pouch, and let no one see it—exposure will render it powerless. After twelve years, recarve it anew and submit a petition to replace it. Discard the old seal in a secluded cave or ravine where no one treads.

**Establishing the Yin and Yang Altar Formations**
The Master says: When establishing a grand ritual, select a room at the *gen* (northeast) door, set up the Hall of the Divine Tiger facing south, and arrange tables for the officials and generals with all requisite incense and flowers. Then, within the hall, construct the Yang Radiance Passage Altar on the left and the Yin Spirit Seizing Soul Altar on the right, each three feet and six inches in diameter, leveled and aligned. Place altar placards and the tablets of the Left and Right Wardens of the Underworld Prison. Enclose the entire chamber with white silk curtains to shield it from dust.

First, perform the ritual offering to the Primordial Jade Tablet according to protocol, then establish the altars. Prepare tea, wine, fruit, and fern shoots to sacrifice to the Divine Tiger officials and generals. Follow the prescribed steps: transform the spirit, pace the *wai* (zigzag), and proceed with the sequential summoning and sealing.

Draw upon the earth with a sword. Place the male left seal at the center of the Yang Altar and the female right seal at the center of the Yin Altar. On the central table, keep a single bright lamp burning. Affix the Guiding Youth Talisman and all Divine Tiger talismans. Fill two vessels with water and immerse one Divine Tiger Seizing Soul Talisman in each, placing them beneath the altar placards. Invoke the officials and generals to pursue the soul and manifest at the altar.

Next, take three Manifestation Talismans: burn one with the petition and underworld paper money, submerge one in water, and consume the last yourself. Hold the talisman water in your left hand, grasp the sword in your right, recite the *Tianyi Beizu* incantation seven times, and draw the *qi* of the Ghost Gate into the water. Sprinkle it over both altars, reserving the remainder on the table. Draw the curtains, seal the hall’s door, and forbid entry. Only when the appointed time for summoning arrives should the curtains be opened. Place banners to the left and right of the altars.

Use the Talismans of Manifestation, Dark Release, Communication, and Vision—burn them in water and sprinkle the mixture over the youth’s body. Instruct the youth to point out the signs. After a long while, faint traces may appear. If the bereaved’s devotion is sincere, the spirit’s form will manifest, and words may be exchanged as clearly as with the living. If the living weep in sorrow, the startled soul will flee far away. If the living rejoice, the spirit will fully appear. Beware of anger, for it is forbidden. Do not summon frivolously; no other prohibitions apply.

**Establishing the Eight Gates Summoning Soul Altar Formation**
The Master says: To summon a soul and manifest its form, set up eight gates in the center of the Divine Tiger Hall, with the Summoning Soul Altar positioned eight feet away. Alternatively, establish it in a clean, open space outdoors, spreading fine yellow earth four feet and nine inches wide. Encircle it with eight gates, bound by red silk cords twisted leftward, nine feet or fifteen feet long depending on the space. Use sixteen iron nails, each six inches long, to secure the gates. Place white placards at each gate inscribed with their names and the eight talismans.

Set a clean basin of immortal elixir broth at the altar’s center, immersing the *Tieji Tai Baoguang Zhang* (Iron Trace Terrace Treasure Light Chapter). Bind pure mallow stalks into a human figure, dressing it in the deceased’s former attire. Place the Great Brahma Concealed Script inside, crown it with the Great Ascension to Heaven Certificate, and suspend it from a scale’s hook so the mallow figure hovers three to five inches above the ground.

In advance, prepare a seven-foot-two-inch white silk banner for summoning the soul—one for a male spirit, one for a female, each three feet and six inches long. Attach them to an eight-foot-four-inch bamboo pole. Erect the male banner on the altar’s left (inscribed with *Tieji Tai*) and the female banner on the right (inscribed with *Baoguang Zhang*). Place the central summoning banners as needed.

When the time comes, have a young boy and girl hold the two banners at the ritual master’s sides. Follow the protocol to summon and sacrifice to the officials and generals, then invoke the deceased’s soul. The master, holding the banner in the right hand and forming the Summoning Soul mudra with the left, taps the teeth nine times, whistles three times to the left, and calls three times to the right. Chant the Summoning Soul Incantation and the Yin-Yang Dipper Chapter, then recite the Summoning Soul and Pursuing Soul incantations. Visualize the ritual in progress as the banner covers the mallow figure.

If the yin soul arrives, the banner will grow heavy, bending the bamboo pole until the mallow figure’s scale touches the ground. Then, guide the spirit to bathe, change clothes, face the true, and receive deliverance. If the refinement and deliverance have been long delayed, the deceased may fear the living’s yang *qi* and scatter the yin soul. Use the banner to gather it back to the Summoning Soul Altar, entering through the Gate of Death and closing it behind. Next, take the altar’s water and sprinkle it in all ten directions with a willow branch to fully restore the soul’s form, making its shadow manifest. When guiding the spirit for refinement and deliverance, open the Gate of Life and lead it out to the altar. This method aligns with the Great Yin Refinement and Deliverance protocol.

It is also said: When establishing the Divine Tiger Altar, one must use the *Five Scattered Chapters* to guard the five directions. Place the *Great Floating Li Earth Diagram* of the Supreme Emperor at the center—summoning will then be immediate. Without this text, the divine officials will lack the harmonizing light and cannot arrive. During the ritual, recite the *Three Chapters of the Demon King* and burn the *Red-Written Jade Characters* and *Eight Mighty Dragon Scripts* within the chamber. For the divine officials cannot be summoned without the true script of the Heavenly Primordial *qi* and the Jade Characters of the Celestial Origin. These two chapters are the supreme prohibitions of the Mystic Capital. The Primordial Beginning summons all the Heavenly Emperors and the myriad spirits of the Three Realms using these very chapters. All ten thousand sages, upon seeing this text, behold the jade light and arrive.

In practicing the supreme Dao of the Numinous Treasure, the key lies in refining *qi* and visualizing the spirit. Only when one’s true body aligns with the Primordial Beginning’s wisdom can enlightenment be attained. Without this, one labors in vain and risks divine punishment. Be vigilant.

The *Five Scattered Chapters*, the *Red-Written Jade Characters*, and the *Eight Mighty Dragon Scripts*—all are revealed within the *Gate of Suppression, Exorcism, and Subjugation*. Alongside these appear the *Yang Radiance Passage-Opening Altar Diagram* and the *Yin Spirit Subjugation Altar Diagram*.

The *Yang Radiance Altar* governs the salvation of the deceased, extending to the myriad ancestors—those long transformed and recently departed, all souls and consciousnesses.

The *Yin Spirit Subjugation Altar* governs the salvation of those who died from illness, violent misfortune, self-inflicted harm, or murder; those imprisoned, bound, or long confined in the Dark Bureau; and all souls of the Nine Netherworlds.

The *Eight Gates Summoning Altar*:
When the soul is summoned, open the Ghost Gate at the Human Gate and close it upon entry.

The *Eight Gates Placards and Talismans*:
Human Dao
Buddhist Dao
Immortal Dao
Earth Dao
Karmic Dao
Divine Dao
Ghost Dao
Animal Dao
These talismans are inscribed on yellow paper placards, each one foot and four inches in height. When the deceased touches this talisman, their soul enters the altar, and all present may witness their manifested traces.

The *Iron Trace Terrace Radiant Treasure Chapter*:
The radiance of the sun and moon illuminates the eight directions.

The *Iron Trace Golden Radiance Treasure Terrace Chapter*:
Mighty light blazes forth,
Dispelling yin and restoring yang.
Souls return to the yin,
Spirit *qi* permeates the eternal.
The Eight Gates traverse the netherworld, avoiding death and harm.
Summoned souls cannot conceal themselves.
This talisman is inscribed on a three-inch piece of yellow silk with cinnabar. Steep it in a decoction of *fuling*, *fushen*, *asparagus root*, *ginseng*, and *rehmannia*, each one *fen* in weight, then place it within the basin at the center of the Eight Gates Altar. After the summoning, sprinkle water upon the altar in the ten directions to restore the yellowed form, reviving the complete soul and manifesting its shadow—this is the treasure of ghosts and spirits.

Another method: Inscribe on green or white silk with cinnabar, seven inches in length and two inches and four *fen* in width, to summon the souls of those condemned to the Unrelenting Hell.

The *Two Altar Banners and Talismans*:
*Iron Trace Terrace Treasure Radiance Chapter*
These two talismans are inscribed with realgar and cinnabar on two banners, which are then erected on the left and right of the Eight Gates Altar. For yang persons, use the *Iron Trace* to summon; for yin persons, use the *Treasure Radiance*.

The *Jade Emperor’s Seal*, aligned with the Northern *qi*.

The *Summoning the Deceased Banner: Supreme Unity’s Return to True Form and Subjugation of Souls Talisman*:
Supreme Lady of the Primordial Beginning,
Purple *qi* traverses the celestial ford.
Gather essence and assemble souls—
Let the messengers appear and present themselves.
At the first summons of the true talisman,
Soul and spirit unite.
The *Scintillating Spirit* subdues the *Flying Poison*,
The *Fetal Light* and *Corpse Dog* devour the *Thief*,
The *Stinking Lung* and *Netherworld Essence* expel the *Sparrow Yin* and impurities.

The *Supreme Jade Edict*:
By the talisman’s union, traverse the netherworld.
Let the Subjugating Soul Messengers
Restore the original form,
Bind and restrain Fengdu,
Wind and fire cease not.
Through effortless transformation, the profound merit of the Great Dao is achieved.

The *Incantation*:
The Northern Emperor’s divine elixir,
All immortals pay homage to the sacred countenance.
May the records of Fengdu descend,
Good and evil repaid in cyclic return.
Suddenly, the suffering of hell is opened,
Sinful ghosts depart the Mountain of Knives.
I ask: what karmic deeds were committed,
That they never passed the gates of darkness?
Pity the lost and deluded children,
With no shore to cling to.
Thus, the true talisman’s essentials are expounded,
Proclaimed to save the world.
*Swiftly, swiftly, as in the statutes and ordinances!*

This talisman follows the Northern Emperor’s seal, aligned with the Northern *qi*.

The *Great Conductor General’s Summoning Soul Talisman*:
*Terrace Radiance, Scintillating Spirit, Netherworld Essence*,
Support the infant, stabilize the *lan* vessel, refine the pure.
Transform the origin, unite the soul, let the stars fly and the marsh overflow.

Heavenly spirit, earthly essence, human hero, ghostly scintillation.

Deliverance from the Eastern Mountain—

The Master says: The summoning soul banner may be made of double-layered white silk, three feet and six inches in length. Inscribe the talisman at the top of the front, and on the banner’s body, write in black seal script the *Supreme Unity’s Return to True Form Talisman*, then overlay it with a red-inked matching talisman, sealed with the *Jade Conductor’s Jade Seal*. Below the talisman, write the name of the deceased. At the feet, record the dates and times of birth and death. Let the Three Hun all attend, the Seven Po accompany; at the hands, write *Banner of the Transcended Spirit*, guiding the way. When the talismans align, the soul’s good thoughts remain unchanged.

On the reverse side, at the top, inscribe the forms of the sun, moon, and Dipper. On the body, write in seal script the *Great Conductor General’s Talisman*. At the hands, inscribe the two sages, their names filled with red. In the center, impress the *Great Conductor General’s Seal*. On the left hand, write: *Male Left Jade Ministry, Commander of the Three Hun and Hundred Nodes, Master Soul, Great Sage Wang Bo*.
